China will invest $100 billion over five years to strengthen its chip industry, Morgan Stanley analysts say, with a focus on creating "national champions" such as Semiconductor Manufacturing International and Spreadtrum Communications.Bill Lu and nine other Morgan Stanley analysts said in a 41-page research report Monday said while this isn't China's first major attempt to make a big leap in the semiconductor market, "this time could be different.""The goal is large but simple — China's semiconductor ambitions are targeted toward areas where it already dominates manufacturing, and where national security is involved," the report said. "It will take several years for China to disrupt new semiconductor markets, but disruptions — notably margin risk — could end up being significant for established players and for the global chip market overall."Morgan Stanley analysts said China is not spreading its investments broadly, but instead pushing for "national champions" in semiconductor segments."These include one national manufacturing champion Semiconductor Manufacturing International, one assembly subcontractor (Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology), likely local DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) and Nand flash-memory production and one semi equipment company and a few fabless companies such as Spreadtrum Communications and HiSilicon," according to Morgan Stanley's report.Opportunities for non-Chinese firms include partnerships such as the one that Intel (INTC) has with Spreadtrum Communications and Rockchip Electronics, and Qualcomm 's (QCOM) joint venture with Semiconductor Manufacturing International.Morgan Stanley analysts also expect opportunities for chip technology licensing companies such as ARM Holdings (ARMH) to find new customers and for chip equipment makers to find new customers. More mergers and acquisitions related to the changing landscape are also likely, according to the report.Intel Price Target CutIn a separate report Monday, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Michael McConnell said after a trip to Asia that he is more positive on fundamentals at ARM, Avago Technologies (AVGO), Qorvo (QRVO) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). Qorvo recently joined the S&P 500 index.McConnell said Nvidia (NVDA) is gaining broader design wins in China following strong orders from Baidu (BIDU), Huawei, Tencent (TCEHY) and Alibaba (BABA).He's "incrementally more cautious" on Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Cavium (CAVM), Intel, Xilinx (XLNX) and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM).Pacific Crest lowered its price target on Intel stock to 35 from 37, based on the weak outlook for PC demand coupled with a delayed launch of Intel's Skylake processors.Intel stock was down 1.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 30.50.The analysts said new products at AMD are not driving design wins at PC customers, while feedback from Asia indicates that Marvell Technology Group's (MRVL) storage business is being affected by solid-state-drive share-loss and "execution problems."RELATED:Chip Leader Inphi Finds Support After Sell-Off.

Apple supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) is expected to post its eighth straight quarter of accelerating earnings and sales growth when the chipmaker reports Q2 results after the market close Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Avago to report earnings per share excluding items of $2.01, up 136% from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue is expected to soar 133% to $1.635…

Stocks pecked out modest early gains Thursday as investors took in a raft of earnings reports, housing and unemployment data and a highly anticipated policy announcement from the European Central Bank.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each added 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average checked in with a 0.3% gain. Volume rose 10% on the Nasdaq and was 5% higher on the NYSE compared with trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today received an early lift from the European Central Bank, which upgraded its monetary stimulus efforts to include heftier-than-anticipated asset purchases of nearly $70 billion per month. Purchases of government and European institutional bonds will begin in March and run for 18 months, ECB President Mario Draghi said. The bank also held its primary lending rate unchanged at a record-low 0.05%.

In U.S. economic news, the Federal Housing Finance Agency said its Housing Price Index gained 0.8% in November. That was a step above October's 0.6% gain and stronger than the 0.3% gain projected by economists.

In stocks, earnings reports helped place financial and chip sector plays under early pressure. American Express (AXP) and Discover Financial Services (DFS) dived 4% and 8%, respectively, after delivering quarterly results late Wednesday. SanDisk (SNDK) shed 6% and Xilinx (XLNX) dropped 10%, also following reports made after Wednesday's close.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) leapt 5% after a healthy Q4 report. That bumped the stock to a new high and out of buying range on its first test of 10-week support since clearing a short cup base in November.
EBay (EBAY) climbed 4% after announcing the possible spinoff of its eBay Marketing unit. The gain lifted shares back to their 10-week moving average in the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.

Switzerland-based Logitech International (LOGI) popped 7%. The mouse, keyboard and joystick maker reported a fiscal third-quarter earnings gain vs. forecasts for an 8% loss. The gain drove shares just above a 15.15 buy point in a six-week cup base.

On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) crumbled 11%. The developer of network optimization software reported after Wednesday's close its fiscal first-quarter earnings beat, with revenue meeting analyst consensus projections. But management gave Q2 earnings guidance below expectations and said the company saw "a marked decrease in the number of deals greater than $1 million" during the quarter. The loss drove shares below their 40-week moving average, but stopped short of an October low.

John Daane was 13 years old when he first worked summers at his father's company, which tested and repaired printed circuit boards. He never left electronics after that, though he didn't take his dad's preferred route. "The advice I got from my father was not to go into semiconductors," Daane, CEO and president of Altera (ALTR), said with a laugh.…

A second straight sell-off picked up the pace into the close, sending the Nasdaq and Dow industrials below their 200-day moving average.The Nasdaq sank 2.3%, as chips and Tesla Motors (TSLA) weighed on the tech-heavy index, while the S&P 500 fell 1.1% and the Dow 0.7%. Volume swelled across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.Global economic weakness continued to take its toll. Economic data were light Friday. Export prices dipped 0.2% in September, more than expected, while import prices fell 0.5%, vs. forecasts for a 0.8% slide.Automakers were the biggest losers, with the group skidding 7%. Tesla Motors gapped down and closed with an 8% loss in fast trade. Thursday evening, the electric-car maker unveiled its D, an all-wheel drive version of its Model S sedan, which may have disappointed some watchers who were anticipating a self-driving car.Chip-related stocks led the downside. Microchip Technology (MCHP), which preannounced fiscal Q2 sales that were below views, plunged 12%. Among other chipmakers, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) gave up 12%, Avago (AVGO) 11% and Xilinx (XLNX) 8%, all in massive volume.Drugstores, consumer electronics retailers and utilities were among the few groups that managed gains.No economic reports are slated for Monday. The stock market will be open, but the bond market will be closed for Columbus Day.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

It was another rough day for the stock market Friday as weakness in semiconductor stocks fueled stiff selling in the Nasdaq.At the close, the tech-laden index slumped 2.3%. The S&P 500 lost 1.2%. Blue chips outperformed for a good part of the session, but the Dow Jones industrial average eventually ended lower, down 0.7%.The Nasdaq and Dow closed below their 200-day moving averages. The S&P 500 ended a hair above that long-term support level.Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday's levels — another day on unequivocal institutional selling.For the week, the Nasdaq lost 4.5%; the S&P 500 3.1% and the Dow 2.7%.The market's tone was defensive again as tobacco and utility stocks outperformed.The biggest decliners in the Nasdaq 100 all hailed from the chip sector. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shed 12% while Avago (AVGO), Micron (MU) and Xilinx (XLNX) fell 11%, 9% and 8%, respectively.The chip sell-off was partly ignited by Microchip Technology (MCHP). Shares slumped 12% after the company preannounced weaker-than-expected revenue for the current quarter.In the stock market today, IPO Dave & Busters (PLAY) debuted strongly in a shaky market. It priced last night at 16, at the low end of proposed range of 16-18. Shares of the arcade and restaurant chain closed at 17.29.Infosys (INFY) was a rare bright spot in the market. The IT services provider reclaimed a 62.26 cup-with-handle buy point after reporting solid earnings. Shares gapped up and rose 6%. It's still in a buy range.

It was a tale of two markets Friday, as a sell-off in chip stocks fueled a precipitous decline in the Nasdaq. Blue chips, however, outperformed.With a little over one hour remaining in the session, the Nasdaq fell 1.1%. It was earlier down by as much as 1.8%. The S&P 500 eased 0.1% while the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Thursday's levels.Top-performing Dow components included Coca-Cola (KO) and Procter & Gamble (PG).The biggest decliners in the Nasdaq 100 all hailed from the chip sector. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shed 12% while Avago (AVGO) and Xilinx (XLNX) fell 9% and 7%, respectively.The chip sell-off was partly ignited by Microchip Technology (MCHP). Shares slumped 10.5% after the company pre-announced weaker-than-expected revenue for the current quarter.In the stock market today, IPO Dave & Busters (PLAY) debuted strongly in a shaky market. It priced last night at 16, at the low end of proposed range of 16-18. Shares of the arcade and restaurant chain were recently trading around 17.18.Elsewhere, Infosys (INFY) reclaimed a 62.26 cup-with-handle buy point after the IT services names reported solid earnings. Shares gapped up and rose 6%. It's still in a buy range but new buys are risky when the market's in a correction.Tesla Motors (TSLA) lost 7% after the company unveiled spruced up features at the rate the company requested.

With the market in a confirmed and ferociously stubborn uptrend, it's time to be on the lookout for strong international stocks near buy points. Singapore-based Avago Technologies (AVGO) neatly fits the bill. On Tuesday, the broad-stance chip developer was trading less than 5% below a 136.38 buy point in the ninth week of a flat base. The company will announce…

Apple (AAPL) iPhone chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) has reportedly approached three peers for acquisition talks, which boosted shares of all parties Thursday. Avago Technologies has targeted Xilinx (XLNX), Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) and Renesas Electronics (RNECY), according to Reuters sources, who added that the chipmaker could spend more than $10 billion on a potential buyout as it seeks to…
Qualcomm (QCOM) got at least one downgrade and several price target cuts Thursday after the company slashed $1 billion from its revenue outlook for its fiscal 2015 ending Sept. 27.
The San Diego-based chipmaker, however, late Wednesday reported a fiscal Q2 beat.
CEO Steven Mollenkopf said the company would take a comprehensive look at its cost structure after losing business to "a large customer," which analysts say is Samsung.

FBR Capital Markets analyst Christopher Rolland said in a research note Thursday that Qualcomm revealed it "was not only underrepresented in the (Samsung) Galaxy S6 smartphone, but also the upcoming (Samsung) Note 5."
Rolland says Samsung has opted to use its own chips in as many as 80% of Note 5 models.
"(Qualcomm) management remains optimistic that the Snapdragon 820 will eventually recapture the GS7," said Rolland.
He says that will be "very difficult," but doesn't rule it out.
Rolland adds that he was disappointed that more specific cost cuts weren't announced, and he lowered his price target on Qualcomm stock to 70 from 72. He maintained a market perform rating.
4G Position Weaker Than 3G

"Stepping back, we think Qualcomm remains the gold standard in today's cellular technology," Rolland said. "However, we acknowledge a growing trend among handset original equipment manufacturers to roll their own apps processors and baseband modems to reduce eventually their devices' costs.
"Additionally, Qualcomm's intellectual property position in 4G LTE is significantly weaker than 3G, as we expect increasing (semiconductor business) pressure over time."

For fiscal 2015, the company sees revenue of $25 billion to $27 billion, a drop of 6% to an increase of 2%, below its prior forecast of $26.3 billion to $28 billion. It lowered its EPS ex items range to $4.60-$5 from $4.85-$5.05.
Qualcomm was down more than 1% in afternoon in the stock market today, near 68. Qualcomm stock has fallen 16% since touching a more than 15-year high near 82 last July.
Other chip stocks were down Thursday after Qualcomm's lowered guidance, as well as weak outlooks provided Wednesday by Texas Instruments (TXN) and Xilinx (XLNX).
Texas Instruments stock was down 7% and Xilinx stock down 1% in afternoon trading Thursday.
In addition, Avago Technologies (AVGO) was down 3%, Cavium (CAVM) 4% and Qorvo (QRVO) 3%.
Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Walkley lowered his price target on Qualcomm to 80 from 88, but reiterated a buy rating.

"While we are disappointed QCT (semiconductor business) missed some key smartphone product cycles in 2015 and realize the stock likely lacks fundamental catalysts for the next several quarters, we believe Qualcomm is well positioned with its technology investments to recover share and improve margins and revenue ... starting in the second half of 2016," Walkley said.

"Longer term, we believe new market opportunities such as automotive, the Internet of Things, networking and other areas through Qualcomm's strong R&D investments combined with a lower share count through the capital returns program can help Qualcomm achieve solid long-term earnings growth," he wrote.

BNP Paribas cut its rating on Qualcomm to neutral from outperform and cut its price target to 68 from 78. Qualcomm also got price target cuts Thursday from Cowen & Co., RBC Capital Markets and Brean Capital.

Intel's (INTC) expected acquisition of Altera might not take place after all, according to a report Thursday from CNBC.

"The two companies have not spoken in more than a week, sources said, as neither party could agree on a price," CNBC reported Thursday, citing unnamed people familiar with the situation. "Those sources said Intel's offer was in the neighborhood of the low $50-range per share, and that the talks had taken place over several months."

The Wall Street Journal first reportedMarch 27 that Intel was in talks to buy Altera (ALTR). In its report, The WSJ said "terms of the potential deal and its timing couldn't be learned, and it is possible there ultimately won't be one."

Altera stock, which jumped 28% to 44.39 on March 27, its highest price since July 2011, fell as much as 7.9% in early trading Thursday, but by early afternoon in the stock market today it was up 1.4% to 42.59.
Intel stock was up 0.3% Thursday. Intel stock has fallen nearly 15% this year.

San Jose, Calif.-based Altera sells to more than 12,000 customers worldwide, going head to head with main rival Xilinx (XLNX) to provide programmable logic devices — electronic components used to build reconfigurable digital circuits. Xilinx stock was 1.2% to 43.07.
Altera Expanding Portfolio
Altera has a wide range of processors and other products for industries ranging from automotive and broadcast to computer and storage, consumer, industrial, medical, military and wireless.

In an interview with IBD in November, Altera CEO John Daane said the company has been increasing its R&D over the last three years — up 63% over that span — as part of a strategy to expand its product portfolio. Now, its FPGAs (field-programmable gate array, or integrated circuits designed to be configured by customers or a designer after manufacturing) are incorporated into servers, which is a new market Altera has pioneered.
Daane joined Altera as CEO and president in 2002, where he oversees more than 2,600 employees in 19 countries.
The potential merger follows an announcement earlier this month that NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) agreed to pay $11.8 billion for Freescale Semiconductor (FSL).
On March 12, Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and Spansion closed a merger valued near $5 billion.

Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, the longtime leader in chips that power personal computers and services, is slated to report Q1 earnings after the close on Tuesday. Intel on March 16 slashed its revenue estimate for Q1 by nearly $1 billion, citing weaker-than-expected demand for business personal computers and lower-than-expected inventory levels across the PC supply chain.
Intel expects Q1 revenue of $12.8 billion, plus or minus $300 million, down from its previous forecast of $13.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million.

Intel expects its data center business to meet expectations, but said all other forecasts have been withdrawn and will be updated on April 14. The company announced Tuesdayit will begin combining the financial results of its money-losing mobile device group with its highly profitable PC unit, as the chipmaker struggles to gain momentum in smartphones and tablet computers.

Despite reports that Intel (INTC) talks to buy programmable chipmaker Altera have broken down, analysts and investors aren't so sure.

Altera stock dived early Thursday following a report by CNBC's David Faber claiming that, after months of negotiations, Intel and Altera had ceased merger talks. The stock, however, rebounded by day's end after several analysts weighed in, speculating the merger could still be a go.

"The two companies have not spoken in more than a week, sources said, as neither party could agree on a price," CNBC reported Thursday Thursday morning that "Altera Corp. rejected an offer of about $54 a share from Intel Corp., breaking off talks to be acquired by the world's largest chipmaker," citing sources familiar with the negotiations.

Altera (ALTR) stock, which jumped 28% to 44.39 on March 27, its highest price since July 2011, tumbled as much as 7.9% in early trading Thursday. But shares closed up 3.2% to 43.33 on the stock market today, possibly in response to several analysts' reports that the deal may still be alive.
Intel-Altera Deal Still Makes Sense

Raymond James analysts Hans Mosesmann and Melissa Fairbanks said in a research note after CNBC's report that they "would not be surprised if today's news was leaked by Intel in an attempt to compel Altera to reach an agreement."
Mosesmann and Fairbanks wrote that "such a move could backfire, with Intel demonstrating weakness and remaining in a defensive position."

Summit Research Partners analyst Srini Sundararajan said in a research note Thursday afternoon that "despite the news that the Intel-Altera deal is a no-go for now, the rationale still exists for a deal, though the price seems to be too high (Intel apparently walked away at $54, per Bloomberg)," he said.

"We thought it important to review the rationale for such a deal one more time: The two primary reasons why Intel wanted Altera are enhancing its server capability using FPGAs (field-programmable gate array, or integrated circuits designed to be configured by customers or a designer after manufacturing), and Intel's preference to keep its foundry business looking good (i.e. potentially not losing marquee clients such as Altera).
Sundararajan said a buyout by Intel "is better than a partnership (with Altera), though now a partnership may be the best option, with Intel trying harder to make it a win-win."
Investors May Question Altera
RBC Capital Markets analyst Doug Freedman in a research report Thursday said that Altera investors will question why management walked away.

"If in fact management did turn down a $50+ offer, investors will want to know what kind of plans management has to achieve a $50+ stock price in the next number of years," Freedman said. "We do not think that other bidders are interested in matching that or offering a higher price. We do think that other bidders could be interested in the business, but perhaps at a $45 offer."

Freedman said a deal between Avago Technologies (AVGO) and Altera "could be a much better business synergy" with better product portfolio synergies than between Intel and Altera. Avago is a highly rated radio frequency chipmaker whose products are in the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6 and the Samsung Galaxy S6 smartphone.

Northland Securities analyst Gus Richard in a research report said he expects Altera to "come under a huge amount of pressure to take that offer," noting that Altera "earnings aren't going to be that great."
Intel stock closed down a fraction at 31.24. Intel stock has fallen nearly 15% this year.

The Wall Street Journal first reported March 27 that Intel was in talks to buy Altera. In its report, the WSJ said "terms of the potential deal and its timing couldn't be learned, and it is possible there ultimately won't be one."

San Jose, Calif.-based Altera sells to more than 12,000 customers worldwide, going head to head with main rival Xilinx (XLNX) to provide programmable logic devices — electronic components used to build reconfigurable digital circuits.
Xilinx shares closed up 1.8% at 43.33.
Altera Expanding Portfolio
Altera has a wide range of processors and other products for industries ranging from automotive and broadcast to computer and storage, consumer, industrial, medical, military and wireless.

In an interview with IBD in November, Altera CEO John Daane said the company has been increasing its R&D over the last three years — up 63% over that span — as part of a strategy to expand its product portfolio. Now, its FPGAs are incorporated into servers, which is a new market Altera has pioneered.
Daane joined Altera as CEO and president in 2002, where he oversees more than 2,600 employees in 19 countries.
The potential merger follows an announcement earlier this month that NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) agreed to pay $11.8 billion for Freescale Semiconductor (FSL).
On March 12, Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and Spansion closed a merger valued near $5 billion.
Intel Reports Earnings Tuesday

Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, the longtime leader in chips that power personal computers and services, is slated to report Q1 earnings after the close on Tuesday. Intel on March 16 slashed its revenue estimate for Q1 by nearly $1 billion, citing weaker-than-expected demand for business personal computers and lower-than-expected inventory levels across the PC supply chain.
Intel expects Q1 revenue of $12.8 billion, plus or minus $300 million, down from its previous forecast of $13.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million.

Intel expects its data-center business to meet expectations, but said all other forecasts have been withdrawn and will be updated on April 14. Intel said Tuesday that it will begin combining the financial results of its money-losing mobile device group with its highly profitable PC unit, as the chipmaker struggles to gain momentum in smartphones and tablet computers.

Altera (ALTR) stock soared just before the close Friday on a Wall Street Journal report that Intel is in talks to acquire the chipmaker. The deal would likely be No. 1 chipmaker Intel's biggest acquisition, if it goes through. Altera's market capitalization is roughly $11.5 billion.
The Wall Street Journal reported that "terms of the potential deal and its timing couldn't be learned, and it is possible there ultimately won't be one."
Neither Altera nor Intel immediately responded to IBD's request for comment on the report.

Altera stock jumped 28% Friday to 44.39, its highest price since July 2011, all in the last 20 minutes of the session, following the Wall Street Journal report. Altera stock was up more than 1% in after-hours trading Friday. Intel stock rose 6.4% in the regular session.

San Jose, Calif.-based Altera, which sells to more than 12,000 customers worldwide, goes head to head with main rival Xilinx (XLNX) to provide programmable logic devices — electronic components used to build reconfigurable digital circuits. Xilinx stock rose nearly 6% Friday.
Altera has a wide range of processors and other products for industries ranging from automotive and broadcast to computer and storage, consumer, industrial, medical, military and wireless.

In an interview with IBD in November, Altera CEO John Daane said the company has been increasing its R&D over the last three years — 63% over that span — as part of a strategy to expand its product portfolio. Now its FPGAs (field-programmable gate array, or integrated circuits designed to be configured by customers or a designer after manufacturing) are incorporated into servers, which is a new market Altera has pioneered.
Daane joined Altera as CEO and president in 2002, where he oversees more than 2,600 employees in 19 countries.

The potential merger follows an announcement earlier this month that NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) agreed to pay $11.8 billion for Freescale Semiconductor (FSL). On March 12, Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and Spansion (COD) closed a merger valued near $5 billion.
Intel Lowered Guidance

The potential merger comes after Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel on March 16 slashed its revenue estimate for Q1 by nearly $1 billion, citing weaker-than-expected demand for business personal computers and lower-than-expected inventory levels across the PC supply chain.

Intel, the longtime leader in chips that power PCs and servers, expects Q1 revenue of $12.8 billion, plus or minus $300 million, down from its previous forecast of $13.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million.

"The company believes the changes to demand and inventory patterns are caused by lower-than-expected Windows XP refresh in small and medium business and increasingly challenging macroeconomic and currency conditions, particularly in Europe," Intel said in a press release on March 16.
Intel noted that its data center business is meeting expectations, but said all other forecasts have been withdrawn and will be updated when Intel reports Q1 earnings on April 14.

Canaccord Genuity analyst Matthew Ramsay said in a March 17 research report that, "While (Intel) mobile losses remain heavy, we believe Intel's modem/system-on-chip technology is gradually closing the gap in a quickly thinning herd of competitors."

Ramsay maintained a hold rating on Intel stock on concerns Intel's initial outlook for flat year-over-year PC units in 2015 was too optimistic and on other concerns, including foreign exchange issues caused by the strong U.S. dollar.
In 2010, Intel made its biggest acquisition to day, buying security software maker McAfee for $6.59 billion.

There's been a flurry of mergers and acquisitions as China's government encourages private equity firms to make investments, says Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis. Six semiconductor companies have been acquired…
Semiconductor firm Xilinx (XLNX) plunged 6% Thursday after it issued a soft earnings report and outlook late Wednesday, in what is shaping up to be a bad earnings season for chipmakers.

For the fiscal third quarter ended Dec. 27, Xilinx's sales rose 1% over the year-earlier quarter to $593.5 million, $23 million below analysts' consensus, according to Thomson Reuters. Earnings of 62 cents a share beat consensus by a penny, but that included a 2-cents-a-share tax benefit, and represented a 7% drop from last year.
Xilinx said sales in the current quarter should drop 2%, missing analysts' expectation of 2% growth.

"Management's cautious commentary raises concerns about near-term chip demand from industrial and wireless infrastructure customers, in particular," wrote Morningstar analyst Peter Wahlstrom in a research note. "We expect the shares of peer Altera (ALTR) to also come under pressure following Xilinx's lackluster outlook."
Altera stock was down, but just a fraction, in midday trading on the stock market today.
Xilinx had traded as low as 37.20 Thursday but was near 39 in midday trading. Nomura analyst Stuart Jeffrey lowered his price target on Xilinx stock to 44 from 46 but maintained a buy rating.

"While the sales performance continues to disappoint, we believe that forward estimates could likely be reset, comps are favorable and valuation should provide some support," he wrote in his research note.
IBD's two semiconductor groups are both in the top 10 of the IBD's Industry Group Ranking, but they've been getting pounded in the earnings season so far.
Sandisk (SNDK) was down nearly 4% Thursday after it issued soft guidance late Wednesday. Last week, industry giant Intel (INTC) also guided lower than expected.

Stocks opened mixed Wednesday as earnings results drove the bulk of early market activity.
The Nasdaq rose 0.2%. The S&P 500 wrestled to hold a fractional gain. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged, down 0.2%.
Volume was mixed in the stock market today, up 10% on the Nasdaq and down 4% on the NYSE.

In stocks, Delta Air Lines (DAL) climbed more than 2% after its Q2 earnings met estimates and revenue narrowly beat views. The stock is seven weeks into a consolidation, working to form a bottom and retake its 50-day moving average.

Broadcom (BRCM) muscled up 4% in powerful trade. The communications-chip company reported late Tuesday its Q2 EPS slipped less than expected, although revenue dipped 2%, more than projected. But margins were wider than anticipated, Q3 revenue guidance was above expectations and management announced it would trim 2,500 jobs as it exits its baseband chip business.

On the downside, Xilinx (XLNX) collapsed 18% after missing its fiscal Q1 revenue forecasts late Tuesday and paring Q2 revenue guidance below views. Both Bank of America and BMO Capital downgraded the stock early Wednesday.

Among leaders, 3-in-5 of the IBD 50 listed stocks advanced at the start of trade. Losses were moderate, with only Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT), Ambarella (AMBA) and Arris Group (ARRS) slipping more than 1%.

On the upside, Biogen Idec (BIIB) popped 12% after blowing past second-quarter sales and earnings forecasts and raising full-year EPS and revenue guidance to well above expectations. The stock broke out past a 333.07 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Lithia Motors (LAD) jumped 5% on positive second-quarter results. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) sank 6% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slipped 2%.On the upside, IBD 50 stock LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 2% as it continues to climb the right side of a deep, cup-type base with a 276.28 buy point.D.R. Horton (DHI), Luxoft (LXFT), Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) and Amdocs (DOX) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data scheduled for Tuesday include import and export prices for October and wholesale inventories for September.
Xilinx's (XLNX) stock was down more than 3% in afternoon trading Thursday, one day after the chipmaker gave a weaker-than-expected outlook for the current quarter.
Xilinx's chips are used in wireless communications, industrial, medical and aerospace products, among other sectors.

For its fiscal Q2 ended Sept. 28, Xilinx reported earnings per share minus items of 58 cents, up 26% from 46 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 52 cents.
Revenue rose 10% to $598.9 million, where analysts had expected $588.2 million.

But Xilinx expects sales for the current quarter to be up 2% to down 2% sequentially. Analysts had expected revenue of $608 million, up 1.5% vs. Q2 and up 19% from the year-earlier quarter. On Thursday analysts reduced their revenue estimate to $601 million.
Analysts also expect EPS ex items of 55 cents, up 45%.
At least two investment banks cut their Xilinx ratings. Raymond James cut its rating on Xilinx stock to market perform from outperform, while Piper Jaffray cut its rating to neutral from overweight.

Chip stocks are showing up with increasing frequency in the New Highs List and in Stock Spotlight. Suddenly they are emerging as market leaders. The Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group ranked No. 18 last week out of the 197 groups tracked by IBD. It was No. 58 just six weeks ago. Cavium (CAVM) designs systems on a chip for the networking,…
The bears slammed chip designer Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) hard in 2010-11.
After hitting a high in late April 2010, the stock began an 18-month decline. The price fell about 63%.

Decelerating earnings growth eventually confirmed the price decline. The first instance of slower earnings growth (82% vs. the previous quarter's 333% growth) was reported July 28, 2010 — three months after the stock began to fall.
This is a good example of why IBD-style investors time their exits by the chart rather than the fundamentals. By late July, Monolithic had already fallen 24% off its high.
Monolithic has recovered nicely since those troubled days of 2010-11.
Earnings grew 22% and most recently 52% on a year-ago basis in the past two quarters. Revenue popped 16% and 32% in the same periods.
The Street expects EPS to jump 53% in the current quarter on a 17% revenue increase.
The stock is consolidating in a shallow pattern along its 10-week moving average.
Xilinx (XLNX) also is in the chip designer industry group.
The company showed spotty earnings and sales from mid-2011 through mid-2013. In the past two quarters, Xilinx grew earnings 7% and 76% on revenue gains of 10% and 15%.
Analysts expect Q1 earnings to grow 17% on a 15% increase in revenue.
Xilinx can claim a new factor. The company has a new chip wafer format. The 28-nanometer chips allow electronics makers to create mobile devices that run content-rich applications on low power.

The stock cleared a cup-with-handle pattern in mid-January. Volume was strong on the breakout. However, the stock struggled soon after the breakout. Xilinx fell almost 5% under the 46.80 buy point. The semiconductor sector is a big one, filled with chipmakers, chip-equipment makers and fabless firms. Of the three, IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group, comprised of chip designers, ranked the highest at No. 31 in IBD's 197 Industry Group Rankings as of Monday. Xilinx (XLNX) designs programmable logic devices (PLDs). Persistent weakness in the personal computer market has been a head wind…

Xilinx (XLNX), a specialist in complex programmable semiconductor chips, has engineered a positive turnaround. On Tuesday, the San Jose, Calif.-based firm said fiscal third-quarter sales jumped 15% vs. a year ago to $586.8 million. That marked the fastest increase since the September 2010 quarter and an acceleration from 10% growth in the September-ended quarter of last year. Earnings increased 76%…
Stocks remained in the red in late trading Wednesday and were on pace to snap a six-day win streak.

Hurt by biotechs and software issues, the Nasdaq dropped 0.8%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Volume was tracking lower across the board in the stock market today.
VMware (VMW) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped 9%. Late Tuesday, the company reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings and sales. But license bookings showed weakness.
Netflix (NFLX) dropped 5%, erasing more than half of Tuesday's advance. Shares bolted 7% Tuesday in reaction to late Monday's better-than-expected quarterly earnings and news of a price hike.

On the upside, Sodastream International (SODA) erased earlier losses and popped 13% after a report said that Starbucks (SBUX) is in talks to buy a stake in the company. Sodastream hit a three-month high. Starbucks shares slipped 1%.
Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) was off its session high, but still up a solid 8% after reporting better-than-expected earnings and sales late Tuesday. The stock hit its best levels in more than 14 years.

Buyout talks between Intel (INTC) and Altera (ALTR) were reportedly renewed after a deal couldn't be reached in April. Intel could pay $13 billion for Altera as it looks to diversify its chip operations amid waning consumer demand for personal computers, according to the New York Post. Intel makes chips for PCs while Altera makes programmable chips for consumer electronics,…

Stocks fought through a tangle of economic data to post modest gains Wednesday, even as oil prices held above $100 a barrel.The Nasdaq, the NYSE composite and the S&P 500 added 0.2% each. Despite firm crude prices, transportation issues outperformed the market, with railroads leading the Dow Transports up 0.7%.Volume was slightly higher on the NYSE and down about 20% on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Tuesday.Apple (AAPL) shares rose fractionally as the company prepared to introduce its next generation iPad tablet computer. Analysts expect a thinner, faster device. Reports have also described it with a front-facing camera that will enable video chatting. A JPMorgan report Monday forecast iPad-like tablet computers would grow to a $35 billion market by 2012, carving into the market for PCs.Another JPMorgan report boosted a handful of chipmakers, raising the broker's view on the sector to constructive from cautious.Fabless chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) popped 5% in strong volume after JPMorgan raised its rating to overweight from neutral. The stock was testing 10-week support for the first time since its December breakout.Texas Instruments (TXN) surged 4%, also in heavy trade. The JPMorgan report raised it to overweight from neutral as well. The chipmaker is testing 10-week support for the third time since a September breakout.Northern Oil & Gas (NOG) slipped only slightly in early trade after reporting fourth-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share, below expectations. Revenue surged 54% to $23.9 million, also shy of views. The stock is extended from its most recent buy point.Crude inventories data are due out at 10:30 a.m. ET, but aren't likely to have much effect. The Fed's beige book for March is scheduled for release at 2 p.m.

Stocks took a sudden turn down in midday trade Wednesday on reports that the nuclear plant problems were worsening in Japan.The Nasdaq was off 0.8%; the S&P 500 and NYSE composite were off 0.7% each. Despite the general losses, advancing issues led declining issues by a 6-5 ratio on both major exchanges. On the IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, winners led by 4-to-1. Volume was tracking down sharply across the board.Semiconductor designer stocks were rebounding after a series of recent price losses.Xilinx (XLNX), which triggered the 8% sell rule about a week ago, jumped almost 4% in heavy volume. In a meeting with analysts on Tuesday, Xilinx executives expressed confidence that it could regain tech leadership from its rival  Altera (ALTR). But the news didn't shake Altera. It was up 4% in fast trade as it regained its 50-day moving average.NetLogic Microsystems (NETL), also in the chip designer group, leapt 6% in heavy volume.On the downside, Apple (AAPL) slid 3% in almost triple volume. JMP Securities downgraded Apple from market outperform to market perform because of a slowdown at a Japan plant. On Tuesday, the stock closed under its 50-day line for the first time since early September.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, coal stocks led the upside. Solar stocks led the downside.

The major indexes retained heavy losses in late-morning action Friday, amid a flurry of corporate earnings reports and the latest reading on consumer prices.
The NYSE composite skidded 1.9%, the Nasdaq 1.7%, the S&P 500 1.6% and the Dow 1.5% each. Volume surged across the board on a day of options expiration.

The Consumer Price Index dipped 0.1% in June, driven lower by falling energy prices and matching expectations. The core CPI, which strips out volatile energy and food prices, rose 0.2% in June  a bit more than expected.
Banking stocks both domestic and foreign were trading lower. Banco Santander Brasil (BSBR) tumbled 3% in rapid turnover. The Brazil-based came public in October of last year.
Acme Packet (APKT) also shed 3% in heavy volume. The maker of border controllers and other telecom equipment retains a highest-possible 99 Relative Price Strength Rating and remains in an uptrend.

Xilinx (XLNX) gave up 3% in nearly triple its usual trade. Stocks were unfazed by a mixed round of earnings reports Tuesday. Major averages were mixed about two hours into the session.

The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.4%, weighed down by weak earnings from IBM (IBM). Shares fell 4% after fourth-quarter revenue came up short. The S&P 500 fell 0.1% while the Nasdaq added 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking lower than Tuesday.

In the stock market today, railroad operator Norfolk Southern (NSC) gapped up on strong earnings before the open. Shares rose 6% to an all-time high. Norfolk cleared a flat-base buy point of 89.09 in December. It's now 5.5% above the buy point.

In the chip sector, Texas Instruments (TXN) and Xilinx (XLNX) rallied on earnings. Texas Instruments hit a 52-week high, rising 1%. Xilinx, meanwhile, extended gains after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 46.80. Shares rose 2% to 48.52.

In the retail sector, Coach (COH) slumped 7% after the company missed earnings and sales estimates. North American same-store sales plunged nearly 14%. Michael Kors (KORS) was a beneficiary of Coach's weak earnings as Kors continues to take share. Kors rose 3%.

IBD 50 component MasterCard (MA) rallied nearly 2% to 83.12 after a 10-for-1 stock split. Other nice percentage gainers in the early going Tuesday included HomeAway (AWAY), TAL Education Group (XRS) and WuXi PharmaTech (WX). All rose 3%.

Stocks opened nicely higher Tuesday, but were near session lows just over two hours into the session.

The Nasdaq rose by as much 0.7% early, but was essentially flat. The S&P 500 fell 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.7%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking lower than Friday, not surprising considering that volume was elevated Friday due to options expiration.
The Travelers Cos. (TRV) and Verizon Communications (VZ) weighed on the Dow. Both stocks fell nearly 3% after reporting earnings.

In the stock market today, IBD 50 component Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) bounced back after Friday's heavy volume reversal. Shares rose 3%. The China-based growth name reclaimed its 10-week moving average last week as it works on a new base.
Elsewhere, Under Armour (UA) was trying to snap a three-session losing streak. Shares rose 2%. It's trying to reclaim its 10-week moving average after giving up the support level last week.
In IBD's Medical-Ethical drugs group, Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) outperformed, rising 5% and 2.5%, respectively.

In earnings news, TD Ameritrade (AMTD) gapped up to an all-time high. Shares rose 4% after the company reported profit of 35 cents a share, up 30% from a year ago. Sales rose 16% to $752 million, the fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth.

Stocks erased some losses in afternoon trade Wednesday as the indexes tried to overcome a bad start.The Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 0.6%. The tech-leaning index had been down as much as 1% earlier. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite wiped out all but 0.2% of their losses. Volume remained up on the Nasdaq and down on the NYSE.Winners led losers narrowly on the NYSE, but declining issues held a moderate advantage on the Nasdaq. In the IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, losers led winners by about 3-to-2.Biopharmaceutical company Viropharma (VPHM) surged 8% as it broke out of a seven-week base in almost triple volume. The stock was 3% past an 18.80 buy point. The company's board announced a program to repurchase up to $150 million in shares.Viropharma was No. 44 in Monday's IBD 50. The chart description noted that the stock was building a base and pointed out that it had traded tightly near the base's bottom — a bullish sign.China-based advertising company Focus Media (FMCN) gapped up 7% in volume five times greater than normal. About a week ago, the stock cleared a cup-with-high-handle pattern. The stock is now 6% past the 27.58 buy point. Focus Media is in IBD's 85-85 index, which screens for stocks in the top 15% of the market in earnings growth and price performance.Top chip stocks falling below their 50-day moving average in fast trade included Xilinx (XLNX),  Applied Materials (AMAT) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). The sector in general is taking a beating.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, technology-related groups held the five worst-performing positions. On the positive side, retail and medical sectors were strong.
The past week had its positives. A few IBD 50 stocks broke out, and some U.S. economic reports encouraged investors.
But stocks were also pressured by surging oil prices amid continued upheaval in the Arab world.
IBD's outlook for the market remains where it was a week ago: "uptrend under pressure."
This means growth investors should be especially careful about establishing new positions. You also might want to be raising some cash if you haven't already.
Still, there were those breakouts by leading stocks. While few in number, they offered some hope.

Ebix (EBIX), which provides software and e-commerce products to insurers, cleared an irregular handle at the beginning of the week in big turnover. The stock is now well extended past its 25.97 early buy point.

Silver Wheaton (SLW) topped a 42.44 cup buy point in strong trade. The silver streamer, which reported quarterly results late Thursday, now stands 6% beyond 42.44, meaning it's just past a proper buy zone.

Chip designer Xilinx (XLNX) remains in a potential buying range after moving past a 34.22 entry point from a three-weeks-tight pattern on Wednesday. Chip-related stocks got a lift Wednesday from JPMorgan's upgrade of its outlook for the sector.
Other IBD 50 stocks have been rebounding off their 10-week moving averages.
Among them are longtime stalwarts like Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU).

Volume has been soft for the Baidu and Lululemon rebounds, but above average for Apple's rally. Apple benefited this past week after CEO Steve Jobs took a break from medical leave Wednesday to unveil a new version of the iPad.
Oracle (ORCL) also has been finding support at its 10-week average, and Sina (SINA) regained that benchmark line after falling below it Wednesday.
Sina, a Chinese Web portal, finished with an upside reversal for the week. Its Internet-Content group edged lower to 113th among 197 groups as of Friday.

The major indexes won back some lost ground in early action Monday following a big sell-off to end last week.
The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the Dow and NYSE composite 0.6% each and the Dow 0.5%. Volume tumbled across the board compared with Friday's options expiration-inflated levels.

The drugmaker's stock gapped down after hitting resistance at its 50-day moving average the past several weeks.

Intel (INTC) might acquire Broadcom (BRCM) to speed up its expansion into wireless and communications networking, speculates Nomura Securities in its 2014 semiconductor outlook. Nomura analyst Romit Shah also upgraded Micron Technology (MU) and Xilinx (XLNX) to buy ratings and downgraded Texas Instruments (TXN) and SanDisk (SNDK) to sell. He upgraded Intel to neutral. "Intel's guidance seems doable for the…

ARM Holdings, long the power player among chip designers for smartphones and tablets, has curbed investor concerns of waning potential and is poised for a strong 2014, analysts say.They see several possible growth drivers for ARM Holdings (ARMH), as customers such as Apple (AAPL) and Samsung roll out new products. There's also word that Google (GOOG) might design its own server processors using ARM Holdings technology, according to a Bloomberg News report last week."I think ARM is in a phenomenal position headed into next year," said Evercore Partners analyst Patrick Wang. "It is firing on all cylinders."ARM Holdings is the second-largest firm by market cap in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group, after Qualcomm (QCOM), and before Broadcom (BRCM), Avago Technologies (AVGO) and Xilinx (XLNX).Wang noted that ARM Holdings' stock rode a roller coaster over the past couple of years, dipping below 23 per share in mid-2012 and seesawing the middle of this year before recovering in the fall to approach 50 in October. It now trades just shy of that.For the downs, Wang and others have most recently blamed headlines generated by would-be competitor Intel (INTC), which has made known that it wants to carve out a big share of the smartphone and tablet market. This, the thinking went, would come at ARM Holdings' expense.Rivals And AlliancesIntel, the world's largest semiconductor company, has dominated the arena of chipmaking for conventional personal computers, but ARM, which counts Intel competitor Qualcomm among its partners, has virtually shut Intel out of the smartphone and tablet space. Yet Intel, at its investor day in November, touted expectations that sales of Intel-based tablet computers will surge past 40 million next year, a jump of more than 300%, with smartphone growth to follow."I never want to discount Intel," Wang said. "Intel has deep pockets and they really want a piece of this market."But, he added, Intel executives also said they would consider making microprocessors based on competitors' designs, presumably including ARM Holdings, And since the latter earns royalties on its chip designs, the Intel concession "would seem to balance things out" for ARM Holdings.With the Intel head wind seemingly diffused for now, Wang said, ARM Holdings is now "my top large-cap pick for next year."Other Wall Street analysts have been upbeat too, issuing outperform and buy ratings.An easing of Intel pressure is hardly all that puts wind into ARM Holdings' sails.The Cambridge, England-based company designs the chips that go into iPhones, iPads and a plethora of other smartphones, tablets and other mobile devices. It earns royalties on every ARM-powered device shipped — accounting for about half its revenue — and collects licensing fees for products in development that use its chips.Despite a 2% year-over-year decline for the semiconductor industry in the third quarter, processor royalty revenue rose about 14% for ARM Holdings, according to the company. That missed estimates, but its licensing income swelled nearly 50%, beating expectations. And earnings per share rose 39% on 28% higher revenue, with both beating consensus views.Analysts have expressed concerns about the saturation of high-end smartphones. There are fewer royalties to be had if most people in the market for such a device already have one and sales slow. But many analysts think this could be offset by greater volumes of mid-tier smartphones being sold in high-growth markets such as China and India.Equally important, on the high-end front, was the move made this year by Apple to shift from the standard 32-bit chips to 64-bit chips in its iPhone 5S.Wang said the change was "huge" for two reasons. One, Apple is a major ARM Holdings customer, and two, others will follow Apple's lead.Future DevicesSamsung already has said it will follow suit in 2014. And ARM Holdings generates higher levels of royalties on the faster 64s, making each shipment more profitable."If not for Apple, others would have taken their sweet time getting to it, but now it becomes essential. And that's a nice tail wind for ARM heading into next year," Wang said. "I think ARM really got its mojo back with the Apple move, because ARM is only as good as its customers."William Blair & Co. analyst Anil Doradla agreed. "I like the story; I like the fundamentals," he said in an interview.Doradla has a "market perform" rating on ARM Holdings "strictly on valuation," meaning he is not yet convinced that there is room for substantial advancement for the stock. He said the 64-bit chip development could help drive growth, and expansion of the mid-tier smartphone market in developing countries should provide another boost."That market is going to be very positive," he said. But he thinks the stock may need another "upside surprise" to advance substantially.Wang said Apple may be the one to deliver such a catalyst. Looming from Apple in 2014 is a larger, roughly 12-inch iPad, expected to have a keyboard and other features associated with notebooks and personal computers. It could change the world of business travel, Wang said, and potentially "change the PC landscape." That could boost business for ARM Holdings as well."I think that if and when it comes out — and all signs indicate it in fact will come out — that's the next leg of growth for ARM's stock," he said.In the latest news out of the company, ARM Holdings on Friday said it acquired graphics lighting company Geomerics, and that its technology could accelerate the transition to photorealistic games in mobile.ARM Holdings CEO Simon Segars said on the firm's third-quarter earnings conference call that it is increasingly licensing its chip designs to more companies, and that some of these firms are plowing into cutting-edge areas such as fingerprint recognition and wearable computing, providing new growth opportunities."A record 48 processor licenses were signed in the (third) quarter with 24 companies," Segars said. That included 11 firms with their first-ever ARM license, "many of whom are planning to take our technology into new and emerging markets."Looking toward the fourth-quarter's results, he said, a "record order backlog" and "robust opportunity pipeline" point to a strong quarter for licensing revenue, with a sequential rise in ARM's royalty revenue.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters on average forecast EPS at 26 cents for the fourth quarter and 98 cents for 2013, then $1.24 in 2014.

The Nasdaq ended with a 0.5% loss after having been down as much as 1% intraday. Chips sold off hard. The Philadelphia semiconductor index tumbled 3% and closed below its 50-day moving average for the first time since September. Elsewhere, the NYSE composite slipped 0.2% and the S&P 500 lost 0.1%. Nasdaq volume rose, while NYSE trade fell.
Crude oil lost 64 cents to settle at $104.38 a barrel.

Fabrinet (FN) gapped below its 50-day moving average and plunged 24% in nearly 12 times normal trade. Wednesday marked the closing of a secondary offering of 7.2 million shares. Fabrinet now sits 37% off its February record high.
Altera (ALTR) gapped down and dropped 7% in nearly twice its average volume. The stock closed 4% below a 42.09 three-weeks-tight buy point cleared Feb. 25.
Xilinx (XLNX) dropped 6% and breached its 50-day line. Volume swelled to more than twice its average. Xilinx closed 6% below a 34.22 three-weeks-tight trigger cleared March 2.
Elsewhere, Stratasys (SSYS) shed 6% in more than double its average trade. The stock erased Tuesday's gains in even bigger volume.

On the upside, ViroPharma (VPHM) bolted 7% to a five-year high. Volume was nearly three times average as it broke out of a seven-week base. The stock was 2% past an 18.80 buy point. The company's board announced a program to repurchase up to $150 million in shares.
Weekly jobless claims, trade balance and the Treasury budget will be out Thursday. Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) and Zumiez (ZUMZ) will also report earnings Thursday.

The market is choppy, but some industry groups are doing well. Last week, the Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group rose to No. 36 among the 197 industries tracked by IBD. That's up from No. 41 two weeks ago.
Semtech (SMTC) designs analog and mixed-signal chips used in smartphones, TVs, notebook computers, meters and for communications infrastructure.
The stock is near a multiyear high after clearing a 25.82 high-handle buy point April 5. Even though the market was narrowly mixed last week, Semtech managed to gain 2%.
Semtech will report Q1 results after the market's close May 25. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see earnings rising 23% to 43 cents a share. Sales are slated to grow 17% to $119.1 million.
Ceva (CEVA) is forming a potential square-box pattern, but it's a thinly traded issue.
Altera (ALTR) is holding tightly after clearing a 45.10 buy point from a square box April 20. Its Relative Strength line is already at a new high ahead of price, a sign of market outperformance.

The stock nearly formed a three-weeks-tight add-on pattern last week. But Altera fell 1.13% in the week ended May 6. Generally, the gain or loss has to be within plus or minus 1% to be deemed three weeks tight.
Altera's trading range has tightened in the past two weeks.
Xilinx (XLNX) is just past a 35.52 buy point from a cup base cleared May 5. Although the stock hasn't gained much ground, its Accumulation/Distribution Rating is holding steady at B+.

ARM Holdings (ARMH) shaped a high handle with a 32.28 buy point. But the high handle has a couple of blemishes. First, the handle corrected nearly 15%. Ideally, handles should be contained within 8% to 12%. Second, volume jumped 41% above average in the first down week of the handle.The market is choppy, but some industry groups are doing well. Stocks were mostly lower in late trading Wednesday after Fed officials cut their view on economic growth. Fed members now see the economy growing between 3% and 3.5%, down from a prior outlook of 3.2% to 3.7%.

The NYSE composite lost 0.5%, S&P 500 0.4% and Dow 0.3%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was holding just above the flat line. Turnover continued to track lower across the board. Most indexes were on pace to end their six-session win streaks.
Intel (INTC) trimmed an earlier 6% gain to 2%. Late Tuesday, the chip giant delivered Q2 results above views and gave a strong outlook for the current quarter.
Fellow chipmakers and recent breakout issues Altera (ALTR) and Xilinx (XLNX) lost 2% each after reversing earlier gains. SanDisk (SNDK) also turned lower, slipping 1%.

Elsewhere, Skechers (SKX) dropped 6% in heavy trading. Several semiconductor stocks were having a rough day in front of Intel (INTC) and Mellanox (MLNX) both reporting earnings late today amid signs of weaker demand.

Among chips stocks getting hit, shares of Mellanox were down nearly 5% in late afternoon trading. For the current quarter, analysts are targeting Mellanox to earn 52 cents a share, up 68%, on sales of $105 million, up 54%.
Shares of Xilinx (XLNX) were down 1.4% while shares of Arm Holdings (ARMH) were off 3.7% and Nvidia (NVDA) were down 1.7%.

Intel shares were up 1.4% in late afternoon trade. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Intel to earn 52 cents a share, down 3.7% from the year-earlier figure, on sales of $13.56 billion, up 4.1%.

Broadcom (BRCM) shares were down 3.2%, though apparently due to the potential loss of business from Samsung. On Tuesday Samsung Electronics said it bought mobile phone technology from chipmaker CSR's for $310 million. CSR makes products that compete with Broadcom.

Early signs of trouble came out of Taiwan last month when analysts who poll manufacturing output saw signs of weakness in a country that produces large amounts of electronic gear, as IBD reported. Recent data from AMD (AMD) and reports from Gartner and IDC that PC shipments stalled in the second quarter are contributing to concerns.

And demand for computer motherboards is now expected to only grow 5% in the third quarter from the second, down from prior expectations for 10% to 15% growth, Pacific Crest analyst Michael McConnell said in a report Monday.Several semiconductor stocks were having a rough day in front of Intel (INTC) and Mellanox (MLNX) both reporting earnings late today amid signs of weaker demand.Among chips stocks getting hit, shares of Mellanox were down nearly 5% in late afternoon trading. Fabless semiconductor firms that outsource their chip manufacturing to outside foundries face bigger challenges competing against chipmakers, like Intel (INTC) and Samsung, that own their production factories, says Jefferies & Co. analyst Mark Lipacis in a report.

Jefferies downgraded Altera (ALTR), a fabless firm, to hold from buy, and upgraded Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), which has manufacturing facilities, to buy from hold. It upped its price target on Maxim to 33 from 29.
As IBD has reported, fabless and other chipmakers are slugging it out in the wireless market, competing for design wins in smartphones.

Fabless semiconductor firms specialize in designing chips, but depend on contract manufacturers, called foundries, to provide them with leading-edge production technology. Intel, Samsung and other chipmakers with manufacturing facilities might have an edge in being able to drive down their production costs, Lipacis says.

"We don't expect fabless semiconductor players at the leading edge to derive cost benefits like they used to," he wrote. "Over the next three to five years, we think exponential growth in leading-edge factory costs will undermine the cost per transistor declines the industry has come to rely on.

"We expect this will translate to a structural shift that will benefit integrators on mature process nodes (Maxim, Broadcom (BRCM), Texas Instruments (TXN), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), challenge fabless players on the leading edge ( Nvidia (NVDA), Altera, and Xilinx (XLNX), and drive unexpected share gains for Intel and Samsung," he said.
Altera shares were down 2.5%, near 33.90, in early trading Thursday, while Maxim was up 1.3%, near 26.42. Intel shares were up a fraction.

European chipmaker Infineon on Tuesday warned that its sales and earnings would be less than expected this year, and shares of some broad-based chipmakers, such as Texas Instruments, fell Wednesday as a result, as IBD reported.Fabless semiconductor firms that outsource their chip manufacturing to outside foundries face bigger challenges competing against chipmakers, like Intel (INTC) and Samsung, that own their production factories, says Jefferies & Co. analyst Mark Lipacis in a report.Jefferies downgraded Altera (ALTR), a fabless firm, to hold from buy, and upgraded Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), which has manufacturing facilities, to buy from hold. The Nasdaq composite tacked on 0.4%, the NYSE composite 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%. Volume fell across the board, according to preliminary data.

The market appeared to draw encouragement from the Fed's beige book report, which said economic activity continued to expand at a modest to moderate pace in January and early February. But stocks continued to get pressured by higher oil prices spurred by upheaval in northern Africa and the Middle East. There were reports Wednesday of bombing raids near Libya's oil terminals.
Chip-related stocks got a boost from JPMorgan's bullish outlook for the sector. The bank also upgraded chip designer Xilinx (XLNX) to overweight, sparking a 6% gain for Xilinx in heavy volume.

Xilinx cleared a 24.22 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. You could also view the stock's move as a rebound off its 10-week moving average. It was testing support at its 10-week line for the first time since a December breakout. Xilinx has earned an IBD Composite Rating of 97.

Apple (AAPL) added 1% in above-average turnover, helped by CEO Steve Jobs' surprise appearance at a company event to take the wraps off a new version of the iPad. Jobs has been on medical leave, worrying some investors. He said the iPad 2 — faster and thinner than Apple's original tablet computer — will start shipping on March 11 in the U.S. The tech giant, currently holding a 93 Composite Rating, has been bouncing off support at its 10-week moving average. It's about 3% off an all-time high reached Feb. 16.

The notable companies expected to report earnings Thursday include Silver Wheaton (SLW), Spreadtrum Communications (SPRD), AmBev (ABV) and Kroger (KR) . The day's economic news will include fresh data for chain-store sales and jobless claims.

Altera's (ALTR) third-quarter sales slipped, surprising analysts who were looking for a slight increase, and fourth-quarter sales are seen dropping further. The maker of programmable logic devices also earned 57 cents a share, 17% less than a year earlier and 2 cents below Wall Street forecasts. Sales edged down 1% to $522.5 million, missing views of $541.6 million. But in…
The rapid buildout of next-generation networks across the globe has been a boon to chipmakers over the past several quarters.
Financial growth has been robust across the sector. Meanwhile, shares of many semiconductor firms are trading at their highest point in years.
The challenge now is maintaining growth as prior-year comparisons get tougher and some markets begin to mature.
Chipmaker Altera (ALTR) has come face to face with that challenge. The company makes programmable chips and other gear used in wireless, computer networking, military, automotive and industrial gear.

Altera has been on an extended run of robust financial growth thanks to heavy demand on a number of fronts, including the rise of 4G networks in developed countries and the buildout of 3G networks in developing countries.

The company had delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit earnings growth before last quarter, when it fattened the bottom line 36%. Sales have risen at least 36% in each of the past five quarters.
Altera's shares touched a 10 1/2-year high of 49.59 on April 29.
Shift To Devices

One reason for Altera's success is the ongoing shift to the kind of programmable logic devices (PLDs) it specializes in. PLDs are used in cellphone base stations, network routers, digital cameras and other items. These chips offer greater flexibility than other chips and are often more cost-effective.
Industry researcher Gartner recently estimated that PLD shipments will enjoy 15.6% annual compounded growth from 2009 to 2014. That compares with 9.6% growth over the entire semiconductor sector.
The strength of its end markets is one reason Altera trades at a premium to the sector as a whole. The company also earns high marks for the execution of its growth strategy, analysts say.
"Given the company's growth vector and high margins, this premium is deserved," Citigroup's Glen Yeung noted in a report.

Altera's main rival in the PLD space is Xilinx (XLNX), which is also based in San Jose. Though Xilinx's financial growth has been similar to Altera's over the last several quarters, its shares trade at around 25% less.

Both firms have benefited from a rise in wireless communication infrastructure spending over the past few years. And both face the prospect of much slower financial growth as some of those markets cool down, and as prior-year comparisons become tougher.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Xilinx to report lower earnings in each of the next four quarters, ending a run of six straight quarters of double-digit-or-better growth.
Altera should grow earnings 10% this quarter. After that, analysts expect it to report three straight quarters of lower profit.
Last quarter, the company logged earnings of 68 cents a share. That was up from 50 cents the prior year and came in 3 cents above Thomson Reuters estimates.
Revenue climbed 33% to $535.8 million, below consensus estimates for $537.9 million.
Operating margins improved to 46% from 40% a year earlier, thanks in part to a lower one-time charge for employee compensation.
A slowdown in some end markets during the quarter was offset by strength in other markets, analysts say.

In a report, JPMorgan analyst Christopher Danely noted that Q1 sales to the Asia-Pacific region decreased 14% from the previous quarter "due to a slowdown in the telecom and wireless end market in China and India."
But, he added, "North America sales increased 20% quarter over quarter due to strength in the military and industrial end markets."
Sales in Europe increased 12% sequentially, while sales in Japan declined 18% sequentially.
Sales to the telecom and wireless end markets fell 14% sequentially. Sales to the industrial automation, military and automotive end markets increased 25% quarter over quarter.
Inventory Correction
Though most analysts sound upbeat about the results, there are a few concerns. One is Altera's ability to implement its inventory correction strategy and improve lead times to customers.

"Although we believe Altera is mostly through the inventory correction," wrote Danely, "we remain a little concerned that the correction could be so small when Altera is outgrowing its customers, the semiconductor industry and its competitor so much."
Overall, however, Wall Street embraced the quarter. The company's stock price rose 4% the day after it reported Q1 results.

CEO John Daane said in a prepared statement, "Despite the anticipated slowdown in first-quarter sales following a remarkable 2010 growth year, we experienced double-digit sequential growth in our 40-nm based devices, as these products are now entering the best part of their growth phase."
On June 2, Altera affirmed its second-quarter revenue forecast of $535.8 million to $562.6 million. Thomson Reuters analysts expect sales of $548.7 million.

Altera is slated to announce Q2 results after the close on July 19. Analysts expect earnings of 64 cents a share, up from 58 cents a year earlier.The rapid buildout of next-generation networks across the globe has been a boon to chipmakers over the past several quarters.Financial growth has been robust across the sector. Meanwhile, shares of many semiconductor firms are trading at their highest point in years.The challenge now is maintaining growth as prior-year comparisons get tougher and some markets begin to mature.Chipmaker Altera (ALTR) has come face to face with that challenge. The company makes programmable chips and other gear used in wireless, computer networking, military, automotive and industrial gear.Altera has been on an extended run of robust financial growth thanks to heavy demand on a number of fronts, including the rise of 4G networks in developed countries and the buildout of 3G networks in developing countries.The company had delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit earnings growth before last quarter, when it fattened the bottom line 36%. Sales have risen at least 36% in each of the past five quarters.Altera's shares touched a 10 1/2-year high of 49.59 on April 29.Shift To DevicesOne reason for Altera's success is the ongoing shift to the kind of programmable logic devices (PLDs) it specializes in. PLDs are used in cellphone base stations, network routers, digital cameras and other items. These chips offer greater flexibility than other chips and are often more cost-effective.Industry researcher Gartner recently estimated that PLD shipments will enjoy 15.6% annual compounded growth from 2009 to 2014. That compares with 9.6% growth over the entire semiconductor sector.The strength of its end markets is one reason Altera trades at a premium to the sector as a whole. The company also earns high marks for the execution of its growth strategy, analysts say."Given the company's growth vector and high margins, this premium is deserved," Citigroup's Glen Yeung noted in a report.Altera's main rival in the PLD space is Xilinx (XLNX), which is also based in San Jose. Though Xilinx's financial growth has been similar to Altera's over the last several quarters, its shares trade at around 25% less.Both firms have benefited from a rise in wireless communication infrastructure spending over the past few years. And both face the prospect of much slower financial growth as some of those markets cool down, and as prior-year comparisons become tougher.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Xilinx to report lower earnings in each of the next four quarters, ending a run of six straight quarters of double-digit-or-better growth.Altera should grow earnings 10% this quarter. After that, analysts expect it to report three straight quarters of lower profit.Last quarter, the company logged earnings of 68 cents a share. That was up from 50 cents the prior year and came in 3 cents above Thomson Reuters estimates.Revenue climbed 33% to $535.8 million, below consensus estimates for $537.9 million.Operating margins improved to 46% from 40% a year earlier, thanks in part to a lower one-time charge for employee compensation.A slowdown in some end markets during the quarter was offset by strength in other markets, analysts say.In a report, JPMorgan analyst Christopher Danely noted that Q1 sales to the Asia-Pacific region decreased 14% from the previous quarter "due to a slowdown in the telecom and wireless end market in China and India."But, he added, "North America sales increased 20% quarter over quarter due to strength in the military and industrial end markets."Sales in Europe increased 12% sequentially, while sales in Japan declined 18% sequentially.Sales to the telecom and wireless end markets fell 14% sequentially. Sales to the industrial automation, military and automotive end markets increased 25% quarter over quarter.Inventory CorrectionThough most analysts sound upbeat about the results, there are a few concerns. One is Altera's ability to implement its inventory correction strategy and improve lead times to customers."Although we believe Altera is mostly through the inventory correction," wrote Danely, "we remain a little concerned that the correction could be so small when Altera is outgrowing its customers, the semiconductor industry and its competitor so much."Overall, however, Wall Street embraced the quarter. The company's stock price rose 4% the day after it reported Q1 results.CEO John Daane said in a prepared statement, "Despite the anticipated slowdown in first-quarter sales following a remarkable 2010 growth year, we experienced double-digit sequential growth in our 40-nm based devices, as these products are now entering the best part of their growth phase."On June 2, Altera affirmed its second-quarter revenue forecast of $535.8 million to $562.6 million. Thomson Reuters analysts expect sales of $548.7 million.Altera is slated to announce Q2 results after the close on July 19. Analysts expect earnings of 64 cents a share, up from 58 cents a year earlier.

The two companies that control the bulk of the market for specialized chips called programmable logic devices are seeing growth rates come back to earth after last year's heady gains. Altera (ALTR) and Xilinx (XLNX) are set to report their latest results on Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively. Programmable logic devices perform many of the functions in computer and electronic systems…

Chipmaker Linear Technology (LLTC) posted financial results late Wednesday that gave an inkling of improving business conditions, and its shares were up 1.5% in midday trading Thursday. Linear designs and makes a broad line of analog and digital integrated circuits used in a wide variety of electronic components. The company's fiscal Q2 results slightly missed analyst consensus estimates, but in…

ARM Holdings (ARMH) gapped up nearly 4% in the stock market today, after Jefferies upgraded the chip designer's stock to buy from hold, though shares were up less than 1% in early afternoon trading. Analyst Lee Simpson cited four growth driver for the next three to five years: ARM's challenge to Intel's  (INTC) dominant x86 architecture in the data-center…

Stock futures pointed sharply higher ahead of Thursday's open, as the dollar fell and overseas markets showed firm gains. Dow futures were up 122 points, slightly below their earlier highs. S&P 500 futures held a 16-point gain and Nasdaq 100 futures were 26.25 points ahead. A large portion of action on the stock market today will be in response to…
Stocks remained off the worst levels of the session Thursday, but recovery efforts have slowed in afternoon trading.
The Nasdaq was again down 0.7% and NYSE composite 0.1%. The Dow and S&P 500 lost 0.4% each. Volume continued to track higher on the Nasdaq, while trade has turned lower on the NYSE.
Many chip issues came under pressure after BMO Capital Markets cut the sector to underperform from market perform, citing signs of softening demand and rising inventories.
Xilinx (XLNX) and Altera (ALTR) were cut to underperform from market perform. They shed 6% and 5%, respectively. Both recently staged failed breakouts.
Broadcom (BRCM), Intel (INTC), Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) and Texas Instruments (TXN) also received downgrades from BMO.
On Tuesday, JPMorgan downgraded Intel, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Nvidia (NVDA) due to fears of slowing PC demand.

On the upside, Netflix (NFLX) again showed relative strength. It reversed early losses and climbed 4% to a new record high. That puts the stock 6% past a 124.10 buy point from a double-bottom base cleared Tuesday.
Elsewhere, gold jumped $16.70 to $1215.90 an ounce. Some gold producers rallied. Allied Nevada Gold (ANV) climbed 5% and regained its 50-day moving average.

Stocks ended little changed Friday despite a round of earnings reports and a surprise drop in jobless claims. Overall, equities were indecisive ahead of next week's Fed meeting and midterm elections.

The NYSE composite climbed 0.3%, Nasdaq 0.2% and S&P 500 0.1%. But a fat loss in 3M (MMM) hurt the blue-chip Dow, which slipped 0.1%. Volume eased on both exchanges.

IRobot (IRBT) gapped up and rallied 9% in more than 10 times average trade. The stock was up as much as 14%, but retreated after hitting resistance near 22. Late Wednesday, the company smashed views with an 80% jump in Q3 earnings. Sales rose 20% but missed views. The company guided Q4 profit between 10 cents and 12 cents a share vs. views for 6 cents. Revenue is expected at $108 million to $113 million vs. views for $102 million.

Sensata Technologies (ST) erased losses and jumped 8% to a record high. The company agreed to buy Honeywell's (HON) automotive sensors business for $140 million in cash. Sensata said that deal will add to earnings starting next year. The stock went public in March and cleared a 20.12 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Sept. 30.

Agnico-Eagle Mines (AEM) rallied 6% to a two-year high in more than double its average volume. Late Wednesday, the Canadian gold producer delivered a 1,433% surge in Q3 earnings, but still missed views.

On the downside, Lubrizol (LZ) gapped down, dumped 9% and sliced its 50-day moving average in huge volume. The chemical maker reported Q3 earnings and sales, missing views on both. But the firm raised its full-year profit outlook to $10.35 to $10.55 a share vs. views for $10.10.
After the close, Coinstar (CSTR) surged 12% after smashing earnings estimates. It also gave an upbeat profit outlook for the current quarter.
Deckers Outdoor (DECK) climbed 6% after beating Q3 earnings and sales views. The shoemaker also raised its guidance for full-year earnings and sales.
First Solar (FSLR) fell 5% in extended trading despite beating top- and bottom-line estimates.
Earnings Friday: American Axle & Manufacturing (AXL), Amerigroup (AGP), HMS Holdings (HMSY) and Quality Systems (QSII).
Economic data: GDP, employment costs, Chicago PMI and Michigan sentiment.
