(Oracle is moving from the Nasdaq to the NYSE.) The…

Cisco Systems' (CSCO) revenue miss and soft outlook, along with an unexpected jump in jobless claims, put stocks down for a third straight day Thursday. But the averages pared a good chunk of losses to finish near session highs.

The Nasdaq lost 0.8% after having been down more than 2% intraday. Networking and chip issues hurt the tech-laden index. Meanwhile, the Dow and NYSE composite fell 0.6% and 0.3%, respectively. Both found support at their 50-day moving averages. And the S&P 500 lost 0.5%.
Volume fell on the NYSE. Despite a surge in Cisco's activity, Nasdaq trade fell. The Nasdaq avoided its fifth distribution day.

Cavium Networks (CAVM) gapped down, swooned 10% and breached its 200-day moving average. The stock had been above its long-term support line since last April. Cavium cleared a cup-with-handle base July 13, but triggered the 8% sell rule five sessions later.

NetApp (NTAP) gapped below its 50-day line and tumbled 9% on more than twice its average trade. Merriman Curhan Ford and Pacific Crest downgraded the network storage firm. The stock closed below its 50-day average for the first time since late May.

Altera (ALTR) and Xilinx (XLNX) fell 6% and 5%, respectively. Both were caught in a BMO downgrade. But they closed well off session lows. Xilinx even closed above its 200-day line after breaching it intraday.

On the upside, Netflix (NFLX) reversed early losses and climbed 5% to a new record high in more than double its average trade. That puts the stock 7% past a 124.10 buy point from a double-bottom base cleared Tuesday.

Kraton Performance Polymers (KRA) turned a 3% loss into a 5% gain. The December IPO closed at a new record high. The company makes materials used in adhesives, coating, sealants and personal care products. It lost a penny a share last year, but analysts see it earning $3.22 a share this year. Kraton's volume is on the thin side. It trades about 162,000 shares a day.

The major indexes gained ground in pre-market action Wednesday, amid a more encouraging slate of corporate earnings.Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow futures all moved higher ahead of the opening bell.In earnings news, Check Point Software (CHKP) reported a third-quarter profit of 63 cents a share, 4 cents above views. The Internet security software maker grew revenue by 17% to $273.2 million, also topping estimates. Shares rose 1% in pre-market trade.First Cash Financial Services (FCFS) topped Wall Street earnings and sales estimates for the third quarter. The pawn shop and payday loan shop operator also guided Q4 profit above views. Still, shares edged down 1% ahead of the open.Tools maker Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) topped earnings estimates by 8 cents a share, beat revenue forecasts, and hiked its full-year profit projection above analysts' target.Others due to report today include Netflix (NFLX), Genzyme (GENZ),  Wells Fargo (WFC), AptarGroup (ATR) and Xilinx (XLNX).
Stocks stumbled to new session lows after Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke began his two-day testimony.

Before the Senate Banking Committee, Bernanke said the economic outlook remained "unusually uncertain" and that policymakers stood ready to take further action if needed. Bernanke again pledged to keep interest rates low for an extended period of time.
The Nasdaq and NYSE composite were down 1.3% each. The S&P 500 and Dow lost 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. Turnover was tracking higher across the board.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) reversed earlier gains and fell nearly 4%, breaching its 200-day moving average ahead of its second-quarter results after the close. The maker of robotic surgical systems is expected to deliver earnings of $2.04 a share on sales of $334.9 million.

Edwards Lifesciences (EW) also turned lower and fell 3%. The company, which makes products to treat cardiovascular diseases, will deliver quarterly results after the close. Analysts see profit rising 10% to 44 cents a share. Revenue is slated to rise 8% to $360.8 million.

Baidu (BIDU) gave up earlier gains and eased a fraction. The stock was up more than 3% at its intraday peak. Baidu will deliver second-quarter results after the close. According to Thomson Reuters, the Chinese Internet search firm is expected to earn 31 cents a share on sales of $276.7 million.

Better-than-expected economic reports at home and China, along with successful debt auctions in Europe, lifted stocks Tuesday. But they ended off the best levels of the session.

The Nasdaq gained 0.6% and the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. They had been up as much as 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Dow rose 0.5%, with 23 of its components closing higher. Caterpillar (CAT), IBM (IBM) and United Technologies (UTX) were the biggest point gains. Volume rose on both major exchanges, according to unconfirmed figures.

Whole Foods Market (WFM) jumped 4% to a near-record high in more than twice its average volume. The stock cleared a 74.55 buy point from an 11-week cup-without-handle base. Despite Tuesday's move, the organic grocer's growth has waned in the past four quarters, from 65% to 27%. Analysts expect an 18% increase in earnings for Whole Food's December-ended quarter.

Monster Beverage (MNST) gapped up and rallied 4% to a new high in more than double its average volume. Goldman Sachs upgraded shares to buy from neutral and placed a price target at 124. Monster Beverage cleared a 98.46 buy point in flat base.

On the downside, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) reversed course and tumbled 7% to a nine-month low. A Food & Drug Administration study found that a drug developed by Watson and Columbia Laboratories did not reduce the risk of premature birth. Volume swelled to more than six-times average.

Nuance Communications (NUAN) reversed from a new high and dropped 2% in heavy trading. The stock snapped a five-session win streak, but remained 11% past a 25.92 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Nuance develops speech and imaging technologies. Its earnings growth accelerated in the past two quarters. Analysts see further acceleration in the current period.
Charles Schwab (SCHW), eBay (EBAY), F5 Networks (FFIV), Fastenal (FAST), Goldman Sachs (GS), State Street (STT) and Xilinx (XLNX) will report earnings Wednesday.

Stocks improved some in late trading, but the Nasdaq remained modestly lower. The NYSE composite rallied 0.6% to a new session high. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 0.2%. Volume turned lower on the NYSE, but Nasdaq trading was tracking higher. Lufkin (LUFK) pared some losses, but was still down 6% in big volume.…

Stock futures pared gains ahead of the open, as housing data and earnings reports sent mixed messages.Dow futures traded down 6 points. S&P; 500 futures slipped 2.79 points, while Nasdaq futures rose 0.75 points. All remained above fair market value.Mortgage refinancing activity picked up for a third straight week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association's (MBA) weekly survey. Rates declined from the start of the year, triggering the refi action. But new mortgage applications fell 1.9% on a seasonally adjusted basis."Purchase applications remain quite low, indicating that home sales are unlikely to pick up any time soon," Michael Fratantoni, the MBA's Vice President of Research and Economics, said in a statement.News was mixed on the home-building side. December building permits rose 17% from the prior month to 635,000, well above views for 560,000 permits. But monthly housing starts slipped 4% to 529,000, below views for 550,000 starts.Tech stocks woke up on the right side of bed, with both  Apple (AAPL) and IBM (IBM) climbing ahead of the open. Late Tuesday Apple logged its best combined quarterly sales and earnings performance since Q3 of 2008. IBM turned in its strongest surge in quarterly revenue growth in a decade.Dutch chip equipment maker ASML Holding (ASML) and clinical research and information technology firm Igate (IGTE) were scheduled to report prior to the open.eBay  (EBAY), F5 Networks (FFIV), Xilinx (XLNX) and Seagate Technology (STX) plan to report after the close.Ears are perked in the airline industry as American Airline parent AMR (AMR) prepares to deliver its Q4 results. Analysts expect a considerably more narrow loss than a year ago, and a 10% gain in sales.American on Tuesday announced a new distribution deal with online travel broker Priceline.com (PCLN). The airline group took a hard hit Tuesday after Delta Airlines (DAL) reported a worse-than-expected fourth-quarter profit result.European markets continued to trade under pressure after an unexpectedly weak jobs report in the UK.
Stocks on Monday recouped some of Friday's big losses. But it wasn't a one-way street. Equities wavered in the face of crosscurrents in earnings, M&A news and downbeat housing data.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.9%, closing just below 2200. Chip issues helped the tech-heavy index. The Philadelphia semiconductor index gained 2.5%. But bellwethers Apple (AAPL) and Baidu (BIDU) fell 2% and 1%, respectively.
Meanwhile, the Dow and S&P 500 rose 0.6% each. The NYSE composite added 0.4%.
Volume dropped sharply on both exchanges compared with Friday's action, which was boosted by options expiration.
Lan Airlines (LFL) rose 4% to a fresh record high in fast trade. The Chilean carrier reports earnings July 28. Analysts are expecting 16 cents a share, up from just a penny a share a year ago.
Airlines were a mixed bag Monday after Delta Air Lines (DAL) reported disappointing sales.

Altera (ALTR) rose 3% in fast trade. The stock cleared a 26.44 buy point from a cup-with-handle base July 7 and has gained 7%. The chipmaker reports Q2 results Tuesday. Analysts are expecting 53 cents a share on sales of $447.10 million.
Group mate Xilinx (XLNX), which has traded in similar fashion to Altera, rose 4%. It erased Friday's losses and then some.
On the downside, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 5% in more than twice its average trade. The stock hit a two-month low ahead of its quarterly results Thursday.
After the close, IBM (IBM) beat earnings estimates by 3 cents, but sales missed views. Big Blue raised its full-year outlook for net income to at least $11.25 a share. Shares fell 4%.
Texas Instruments (TXN) tumbled 5% after it too reported disappointing sales.
The two added to the growing list of companies delivering revenue figures below consensus estimates. Citigroup (C) and General Electric (GE) missed sales estimates Friday.
Earnings Tuesday: Altera (ALTR), Apple (AAPL), Cirrus Logic (CRUS), Goldman Sachs (GS), Linear Technology (LLTC) and VMware (VMW).

Stocks climbed Tuesday as earnings and merger activity trumped news of a potential downgrade to Portugal's debt.

Monday, Adobe Systems (ADBE), Jabil Circuit (JBL) and Paychex (PAYX) all delivered better-than-expected earnings. Toronto Dominion Bank (TD) said it would pay $6.3 billion in cash to Cerberus Capital Management for Chrysler Financial Corp. Dutch chemicals maker DSM said it plans to buy U.S. biotech Martek Biosciences (MATK) for $1.09 billion in cash.
The NYSE composite rallied 0.8%, the Nasdaq 0.7% and the S&P 500 0.6%. However, volume fell across the board.

Wabco Holdings (WBC) gapped up and surged 9% to a record high in nearly five-times average turnover. The auto parts maker raised its fourth-quarter and full-year earnings forecast above current analyst estimates. Wabco makes automotive braking and transmission control systems.

Arm Holdings (ARMH) jumped 7% to a near three-month high in nearly twice its average trade. The stock cleared a 19.38 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. According to a Bloomberg report, Microsoft (MSFT) is due to announce a version of its Windows operating system for Arm's processors, which are in tablets and smart phones.
Hansen Natural (HANS) rose 2% in heavy trading. But the stock finished off session highs after matching its Nov. 26 peak. Analysts see earnings rising 7% this year and 16% in 2011.
After the close, Tibco Software (TIBX) reported Q4 earnings of 31 cents a share, up 35% and 3 cents over views. Sales grew 23%, also above views. Shares jumped 6% in extended trading.
Red Hat (RHT) fell 2% after it reported earnings of 20 cents a share, matching views. Sales grew 21%, above views.
Athletic gear maker Nike (NKE) lost 3% after reporting Q4 earnings of 94 cents a share, up 24% and 6 cents above estimates. Sales rose 10%, slightly above views.
Xilinx (XLNX) warned that its Q3 sales would fall 7% to 9%, which works out to $564 million to $576.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected $604.7 million.

Disappointing sales from Goldman Sachs (GS), IBM (IBM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Texas Instruments (TXN) hammered stocks early Tuesday. But equities battled back to close higher for the second straight session.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?
Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video!

The NYSE composite and the Dow Jones industrials climbed 1.2% and 0.7%, respectively. Both closed back above their 50-day moving averages. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained 1.1% each. The major averages had been down from 1.3% to 1.8% at the session low.
Volume increased across the board.
IGate (IGTE) reversed opening losses and jumped 7% to a 10-year high. Last week, the IT firm beat views with an 82% increase in Q2 earnings and a 43% gain in sales.

Venoco (VQ) turned a 3% loss into a nearly 6% gain. The stock recently found support at its 50-day moving average. Despite the recent pullback, the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has held steady at a highest-possible A+.

Cirrus Logic (CRUS) bounced back from a near 7% loss and gained 4%. Before the open, the chipmaker swung to a higher-than-expected fiscal Q1 profit. Sales surged 118%, the third straight period of accelerating year-over-year growth.

After the close, Apple (AAPL) delivered fiscal Q3 results well ahead of views. The iPhone and iPod maker's gross margin also came in above analysts' estimates. Apple issued a mixed outlook for the current quarter. It expects profit of $3.44 vs. views of $3.82 a share. But revenue is expected at around $18 billion vs. views of $17.03 billion. Shares rose 5% in extended trading.
VMware (VMW) also gained 3% after delivering Q2 earnings and sales above views. The virtualization software maker also raised its full-year revenue outlook ahead of analysts' estimates.

Altera (ALTR) reported Q2 results above views and gave a strong sales outlook for Q3. Shares traded slightly higher after initially rising in after-hours trading. Altera cleared a 26.44 buy point from a handle on July 7.

Earnings Wednesday include: EMC (EMC), Edwards Lifesciences (EW), eBay (EBAY), Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Mellanox Technologies (MLNX), Netflix (NFLX), NetGear (NTGR), Starbucks (SBUX) and Xilinx (XLNX). Meanwhile, Federal Reserve chief Ben Bernanke is slated to testify before Congress Wednesday and Thursday.Disappointing sales from Goldman Sachs (GS), IBM (IBM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Texas Instruments (TXN) hammered stocks early Tuesday. 5:15 p.m. Update:  Earnings, select economic data and Fed minutes sent stocks flying Wednesday. Major indexes charged out of the gate, strengthened throughout the session and never looked back.
The Nasdaq leapt 3.5%, its best gain in nearly two months. Bellwether Intel (INTC) jumped 7% to a nine-month high on its better-than-expected Q2 results and outlook late Tuesday.
Chip issues were big winners. The Philadelphia semiconductor index vaulted 4.4%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite ran 3.2%, the Dow 3.1% the S&P 500 3%. All three regained their respective 50-day moving averages.
Volume shot up on both exchanges.

Changyou.com (CYOU) gapped up, gaining 11% in fast trade. The Chinese online gamer reports earnings July 27. But analysts see profit slipping 1% to 61 cents a share. Growth is expected to return in the following three quarters.
Fuqi International (FUQI) gapped up and climbed 9% in nearly double average trade. The Chinese jewelry retailer continued to bounce back from its recent pullback.
MercadoLibre (MELI) rallied 7% in twice its average volume. The online payment service provider cleared a cup-with-handle pattern.
Goldman Sachs  (GS) was again a winner. It added 4% in heavy trading and cleared a flat base.
Earnings for Thursday: Baxter International (BAX), Biogen Idec (BGEN), Charles Schwab (SCHW), Google (GOOG), IBM (IBM), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Knight Capital Group (NITE) and Nokia (NOK).
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Surge In Heavy Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks screamed higher Wednesday, closing at session highs.
The Nasdaq surged 3.5%, NYSE composite 3.2%, Dow 3.1% and S&P 500 3%
Volume climbed sharply on both exchanges.
Advancers thrashed decliners by more than 9-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 5-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Metals, oil producers and media issues were among the day's top performers. Transportation issues fell.
3:15 p.m. Update: Fed Minutes Add To Hefty Gains
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes added more gains in late trading Wednesday on the Fed's improved growth forecasts.
The Nasdaq was up 3.1%, the NYSE composite 3%, the Dow 2.8% and the S&P 500 2.6%.
Volume continued to track sharply higher on the Big Board and Nasdaq.

According to the minutes of the Fed's June 24 meeting, the central bank now sees the economy contracting between 1% and 1.5% vs. an earlier forecast for contraction between 1.3% and 2%. But the Fed expects unemployment to rise to just above 10% this year. Currently the unemployment rate stands at 9.5%, a 26-year high.
Polycom (PLCM) climbed 4% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings report after the close. Analysts see profit falling 19% to 28 cents a share.
Chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) gapped above its 50-day moving average and climbed 4%. It, too, reports after the close.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Extend Gains In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
With a couple of more hours left in Wednesday's session, stocks inched to new session highs.
The Nasdaq vaulted 3% and the NYSE composite 2.8%. Meanwhile, the Dow and S&P 500 rallied 2.4% each.
Turnover was tracking vastly higher on both exchanges.
Tech heavyweights Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR) rose 5% and 6%, respectively. Citigroup slapped buy ratings on both.
American Dairy (ADY) gapped up and climbed 11% as it continued to rebound from Monday's 44% plunge.

McAfee (MFE) added 2% to its best levels in more than 10 years. The stock cleared a 40.99 buy point from a cup-with-handle base June 29, but waned soon after. Still, the stock never fell 8% below its proper buy point.
The software maker reports Q2 results July 30. Analysts are expecting earnings of 57 cents a share on sales of $466.8 million.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Hold Near Session Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes remained strong, trading near session highs in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
The Nasdaq jumped 2.8%, the NYSE composite 2.6%, the S&P 500 2.3% and the Dow 2.2%.
Turnover was still tracking sharply higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.

Chip stocks surged following Intel's (INTC) stellar Q2 results and outlook last night. The Philadelphia semiconductor index leapt 3.8% to a one-month high. Intel shares gapped up and gained 7% to a nine-month high.
Altera (ALTR) gapped up and rallied 5%. Applied Materials (AMAT) climbed 3%.

Monro Muffler Brake (MNRO) rose 4% and neared a 28.12 buy point from a double-bottom base. The operator of auto repair shops reports earnings July 23. Analysts see profit rising 18% to 46 cents a share.

On the downside, Yum Brands (YUM) gapped down and shed 4% in volatile trading. Late Tuesday, the restaurant operator delivered Q2 earnings above views, but cut its sales outlook for its U.S. and Chinese operations.
12:15 p.m. Update: Breakouts Emerge As Stocks Push Higher
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes yielded broad gains at midday Wednesday, with a spate of top-rated stocks breaking out of bases.
The Nasdaq vaulted 2.7% and the NYSE composite 2.6%. The S&P 500 and the Dow each rose 2.2%.
Volume swelled across the board. It gained 16% on the NYSE and 33% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

Baidu (BIDU) cleared a shallow, five-week consolidation, rising 3% in more than twice its normal trade. The China-based Internet services firm owns a 98 Earnings Per Share Rating and a 94 Relative Price Strength Rating.
Goldman Sachs  (GS) picked up 3% in more than double its average turnover. The banking giant broke out of a five-week, flat base.

Argentina-based online payment service provider MercadoLibre (MELI) gained 5%, breaking out of a 10-week cup-with-handle base. Volume was trading only 34% above average, though, a bit light for a breakout.
Security software maker Macrovision Solutions (MVSN) rose 3%, breaking out of a five-week flat base. Like MercadoLibre, Macrovision has shown merely decent volume Wednesday, at 25% above average.

Meanwhile, telecom services firm Tekelec (TKLC) built on Tuesday's breakout, adding 3% in volume 64% above average. On the negative side, earnings and revenue growth turned lower in the most recent quarter, making Tekelec a riskier breakout.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Retain Gains In Higher Volume

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks finished mostly on the downside Tuesday as Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ) disappointing sales and a downgrade on Goldman Sachs (GS) offset buyout news in the tech sector.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 dropped 0.3% each. They were down as much as 1% and 0.9% at session lows.
Meanwhile, the Dow eased 0.1% and the Nasdaq ticked up a fraction. Cisco Systems (CSCO) agreed to buy Starent Networks (STAR) for $2.9 billion in cash.
Volume climbed on both exchanges following Monday's holiday-softened levels. Starent shares leapt 17%.

Interactive Intelligence (ININ) gapped up and flew 20% to a 21-month high. The maker of contact center communications software sees Q3 results coming in above analysts' estimates. It was the top percentage gainer in the IBD 100.

Gafisa (GFA) reversed morning losses and climbed 6% to a new 52-week high. That marked the Brazilian homebuilder's seventh gain in the past eight sessions. Analysts see its earnings jumping 91% in 2010.

ArcSight (ARST) gapped up and climbed 3% in heavy trading. But the stock finished near session lows. The software maker delivered triple-digit earnings in the past two quarters, but growth is expected to slow to 18% in the current period.
After the close, Intel (INTC) rallied 5% after it delivered Q3 results above views and gave an upbeat Q4 sales outlook.
Earnings Wednesday: Abbott Laboratories (ABT), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Steel Dynamics (STLD) and Xilinx (XLNX).
Data on import and export prices, retail sales and the FOMC minutes will also be out Wednesday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Waver To Mostly Lower Finish
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks finished near session highs following a choppy session Tuesday.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 0.3% each, while the Dow slipped 0.1%. The Nasdaq eked out a fractional gain.
Turnover climbed sharply on both exchanges.
Homebuilders, Internet-related and metals were among the session's top groups. Computer peripheral and auto parts makers were a couple of the worst performers.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retreat In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks worsened in late trade Tuesday ahead of key earnings reports after the close.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 were down 0.3% each. The Dow and Nasdaq slipped 0.2% and 0.1%.

Intel (INTC) pulled back after touching a new 52-week high. It rose a fraction ahead of its Q3 results report after the close. The world's biggest chipmaker is expected to post earnings of 28 cents a share on sales of about $9.01 billion. Intel raised its revenue outlook in August. Intel's results will be a key indicator for techs and the broader market.
Fellow chip firms Altera (ALTR) and Linear Technology (LLTC) also report after the close.
Rail operator CSX (CSX) fell 2% to its 50-day moving average ahead of its results after the close.
Baidu (BIDU) lost ground for the second straight session. It fell 2% and pulled closer to potential support at the 400 level.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Little Changed In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to drift in narrowly mixed territory with a couple of hours left in the session.
The Nasdaq clutched to a fractional gain. The S&P 500 lost 0.3%, while the Dow and the NYSE composite slipped 0.2% each.
Turnover was again tracking vastly higher from Monday's holiday-depressed levels.

Gafisa (GFA) erased earlier losses and climbed 4% to a fresh 52-week high. The Brazilian homebuilder found support near its 50-day moving average earlier this month. Gafisa's sales accelerated in the latest two quarters.
It's not expected to report third-quarter earnings until Nov. 5.
Rino International (RINO) also bounced back from morning losses. It rallied 4% to a new all-time high. The stock is now 46% past an 18.85 buy point from a cup base.
On the downside, Perfect World (PWRD) dropped 5% as it fell further below its 50-day moving average.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Mixed In Early Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes improved into mixed territory early afternoon Tuesday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.1% after falling as much as 0.5%. The NYSE and the S&P 500 fell 0.3% each, while the Dow slipped 0.1%.
Volume was tracking sharply higher on both exchanges.

Interactive Intelligence (ININ) gapped up and surged 12% to its best levels since January 2008. Based on preliminary results, the software firm pegged Q3 earnings in a range of 28 cents to 31 cents a share vs. views of 15 cents. Sales are also expected above analysts' estimates.
The company will report actual results on Oct. 26.
SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) reversed earlier losses and rose 2% to a new all-time high. The stock cleared a cup pattern in May and has yet to form a new base.

On the downside, Telvent (TLVT) gapped down and slumped 10% in hefty trading. The Spanish IT firm expects Q3 profit to meet or beat analysts estimates. But it lowered its full-year outlook for profit and revenue.

Abaxis (ABAX) gapped down and dropped 5% on a downgrade. Citing tepid sales of its Piccolo testing device, SunTrust Robinson Humphrey cut shares to neutral from buy. SunTrust also lowered its fiscal 2010 and 2011 earnings estimates.

Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 2%, but it trimmed some losses following a downgrade. Earlier Tuesday, Meredith Whitney cut the bank to neutral from buy. Goldman remains about 9% past a 171.04 buy point from a flat base.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses In Brisk Trade
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes traded lower in higher volume at midday Tuesday.
The S&P 500 slid 0.7%, the Dow 0.4%, the Nasdaq 0.3% and the NYSE composite 0.1%.
Volume remained higher across the board.

Bank of Ireland
5:15 p.m. Update: The market took on more water Tuesday, with all the major indexes incurring distribution days, according to preliminary data.
The NYSE composite fell hardest, down 1.4%. The Dow and S&P 500 each sawed off 1%. The Nasdaq trimmed 0.8%, buoyed by semiconductor stocks including Xilinx (XLNX) and Altera (ALTR).
The Philadelphia semiconductor index eked up fractionally.

Initial indicators show trading higher on both major exchanges, the NYSE in particular. If those numbers hold, it will raise the number of recent distribution days to five on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq and NYSE composites, and four for the Dow.

After hours, AeroVironment (AVAV) rose 4% after reporting fiscal Q2 earnings of 10 cents a share, topping analysts' views. Revenue fell short of consensus estimates, but the company reiterated its outlook for fiscal 2010 revenue growth of 18% to 22%, above consensus views.
On Wednesday, the only economic report out will be wholesale inventories, at 10 a.m. EST. The Energy Information Administration reports weekly crude oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. EST.
On the earnings calendar, Hi-Tech Pharmacal (HITK) plans to report prior to the market's open. Bway Holdings (BWY) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) are among the companies reporting after the close.
Indexes Close Broadly Lower

The Dow and S&P 500 each sawed off 1%. Bway Holdings (BWY) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) are among the companies reporting after the close.Indexes Close Broadly Lower
5:15 p.m. Update: Bad news from banks and more weak U.S. retail sales data triggered a broad-based slide Wednesday that ripped through Europe and the U.S.

The skid extended the market's losing streak to six straight days on the Dow, four on the NYSE. The NYSE has given up 6.6% so far this week. The Dow has lost 4.6%.The Nasdaq has slid 5.2% vs. last Friday's close. The S&P 500 carried a 5.4% loss.

Ore miners were Wednesday's hardest-hit industry group with a 7% loss, led by Freeport McMoRan's (FCX) 11% drop. Steel groups, apparel producers and hotels and motels were also among the loss leaders.

After the close, Apple (APPL) Chief Executive Steve Jobs announced he will take a medical leave until June. Jobs put chief operating office Tim Cook in charge of the company's day-to-day operations. Shares, already off 3% in the regular session, got hit in after-hours trade.

Thursday's busy docket will include producer price and initial jobless claims data, as well as two regional industrial surveys from the Fed: the Empire State Manufacturing and the Philadelphia Fed Index for December.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Slide On Bank Worries, Economic Data
BY VINCENT MAO

Banking worries and weak economic data sent stocks into a tailspin Wednesday. The major indexes opened lower and stayed red all session. A round of buying in the final minutes trimmed a scrap of losses.

The NYSE composite tumbled 3.9% and S&P 500 3.3%. The Nasdaq dropped 3.7%, closing below the 1,500 mark for the first time in a month. Meanwhile, the Dow extended its losing streak to six sessions, down 2.9%. Decliners thrashed advancers by 9-to-1 on the NYSE and over 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
According to preliminary figures, volume ended higher on the NYSE, but lower in the Nasdaq.
All 197 industry groups lost ground.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Trim More Losses In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks picked up their rebound efforts in late trading Wednesday, but they were still well underwater.
The NYSE composite shed 3.3%, up from a deficit of 4.6%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each lost 2.6%, while the Dow fell 2.3%.
Volume continued to track higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq.

On the economic front, the Federal Reserve noted further economic weakness in its beige book report. "Most districts noted reduced or low activity across a wide range of industries, although a few districts noted some exceptions in some sectors," said the report. The survey of economic conditions spoke of softness in retail sales, manufacturing and services. Real estate markets continued to be pressured.
Citigroup (C) extended its loss to 22%. The bank has traded nearly twice its average daily volume.

Panera Bread (PNRA) tumbled 7% in heavy trading, slicing its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The operator of bakery-cafes reports earnings Feb. 12. Analysts see profit rising 34% to 83 cents a share.
Chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) fell 2% ahead of its earnings after the close. Profit is expected to fall 8% to 32 cents a share.
Bellwether Intel (INTC) reports Thursday.
Elsewhere, crude oil settled at $37.28 a barrel, down 50 cents.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Slump, But Volume Is Mixed
BY PATRICK CAIN
With the late lunch rally ended, indexes were edging lower again.
The Dow was down 3.1%, the S&P 500 3.5%, the NYSE composite 4%. The Nasdaq ceded 3.3%.
All the Dow components were down. NYSE volume was higher, the Nasdaq's a sliver lower.

Life Partners Holding (LPHI), a recent leader, tumbled 10% in rapid trade. The buyer of life insurance policies clawed back from the morning's 14% decline after finding support at its 50-day moving average.
Rail operator Norfolk Southern (NSC) slipped another 6%. This will probably be the stock's third straight high-volume loss. The company is down 15% on the week.
Shoe company Steven Madden (SHOO) also fell 6%. The high-volume drop sliced the stock's 50-day moving average. That line had been the stock's support for the past few weeks.
On the upside, Raytheon (RTN) gained 4%. The mega aerospace firm may be shaping the right side of a cup-shaped base.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Further From Lows, Still Deep Behind Enemy Lines
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes rebounded only slightly from their lowest levels. But battered financial and energy stocks limited any real improvement.
The NYSE composite continued to lead the retreat, down 3.6% but well off its 4.3% low. The Nasdaq composite and the Dow dropped 2.9% and 2.7%. The S&P 500 sagged 3%.
Volume remained higher on the NYSE but about flat on the Nasdaq, compared with Tuesday's levels.
Each of the Dow's 30 components had lost ground. Besieged Citigroup (C) fell 20%.
On the S&P 500, Raytheon (RTN) posted a 3% gain in above-average volume. The Army said Tuesday that it had awarded the contractor a $75 million deal for a radar upgrade of the Patriot missile system.

Charles River Labs International (CRL) perked up 4%. A provider of outsourced development services to drug and medical device makers, Charles River Labs is trying to shape a base after a sharp, four-month correction.

Nasdaq 100 component Genzyme (GENZ) managed a 2% advance in flat volume. The biotech's CEO on Tuesday provided a preliminary Q4 earnings outlook well above analyst views, as well as solid near-term and long-term market outlooks.

On the downside, Norfolk Southern (NSC) sank 5% to its lowest in 29 months. CSX (CSX) on Monday released preliminary Q4 EPS results that were well below consensus views. Norfolk Southern plans to release its Q4 results after the close on Jan. 27.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pare Losses A Bit Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks tried to rebound after sinking to intraday lows near the halfway point of Wednesday's session.
The NYSE composite slumped 3.9%, S&P 500 3.4%, Nasdaq 3.2% and the Dow 3.1%.
Turnover was again mixed, with NYSE's higher and Nasdaq's slightly lower. Decliners creamed advancers 14-to-1 on the NYSE and 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Leaders crumbled along with the general market.

AECOM Technology (ACM) tumbled 11% on triple-paced volume, slicing its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The drop sent the government contractor below a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
AeroVironment (AVAV) dropped 8% and sliced its 50-day line on brisk trade. The maker of unmanned aircraft systems has staged two failed breakouts.
Tower Group (TWGP) fell 5% in its fifth-straight down day. The insurance firm has given back all gains from its Dec. 30 breakout  and then some.
All 197 industry groups tracked by IBD traded lower.
11:15 a.m. Update: Banks Drag U.S. & European Markets Into Lockstep Slide
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes drilled with a passion in late morning trading. Oil and most commodities slumped as the dollar moved generally higher vs. overseas currencies.
Financial issues led the NYSE composite's 4.3% slide. The S&P 500 bored out a 3.7% loss. The Nasdaq composite and the Dow skittered 3.5% and 3.4% lower.
Volume was mixed, up 8% on the NYSE and 3% lower on the Nasdaq.
All of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD gave up ground, with big banks, coal and solar issues and metals miners surrendering the largest gains.

The Nymex February crude contract slipped $1.10 to below $37 a barrel. Weekly inventories showed a mild rise, but not enough to relieve the current domestic oil glut caused by soft demand and a futures market in contango. In London, the Brent crude benchmark added 76 cents to more than $45 a barrel.
Other commodities were generally mixed as the dollar piled into a third day of gains vs. the euro, but backtracked against the yen.
Private college operators grabbed some early gains, but backed off their highs in late morning trading.
Apollo Group (APOL) held a 50-cent gain, a bit less than 1%, in heavy trading. ITT Educational Services (ESI) was also up just under 1% in equally strong trading action.
On the medical side, patient support system maker Hill-Rom Holdings (HRC) managed a 3% gain in strong trading.
On the downside, online jewelry retailer Blue Nile (NILE) shed 9% on nearly four times its average volume.
Strayer Education (STRA) backed off 3% in busy action, working on a third straight day of declines.

Overseas, markets in Asia booked varied gains. The Shanghai composite bolted ahead 3.5%, its best gain in six weeks, on speculation the central bank was preparing for its sixth interest rate cut since September. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index grabbed a more modest 0.3% gain. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo also added 0.3%.

The picture was far less rosy in Europe and the U.K. Morgan Stanley's warning on HSBC Holdings' (HBC) finances and U.S. retail sales data drove stocks sharply lower. The FTSE 100 had tanked 5.4% heading into late afternoon trading. The CAC-40 in Paris axed off a 4.9% loss and Frankfurt's DAX dropped 4.3%.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Down Sharply On Lower Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks tumbled out of the gate and piled on more losses Wednesday, sending the major indexes further south of their 50-day moving averages.
The NYSE composite dumped 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.6%, the Nasdaq 2.5% and the Dow 2.3%. Decliners swamped advancers by about 12-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges.
Financials were among the biggest losers, with Citigroup (C) leading the pack. It gapped down and dropped 14%. The bank will report earnings on Friday instead of Jan. 22. It did not give a reason.
JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which moved its report date up to Thursday, fell 5%.
Bunge (BG) gapped down and plunged 16% after late Tuesday's move to guide full-year 2008 and 2009 earnings below views. This morning UBS downgraded shares to neutral from buy.
Siemens (SI) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped 12% after warning of tough times ahead. This morning Merrill Lynch cut the German conglomerate to neutral from buy.
9:15 a.m. Update: Financials, Retail Sales Slam Stock Futures
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks futures signaled a vastly lower start Wednesday on concerns over the health of the financial sector and dismal retail sales.
Nasdaq futures declined 17 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 16 points and Dow futures shed 104 points.

Late Tuesday, Citigroup (C) confirmed that it will merge its Smith Barney brokerage unit into a joint venture with Morgan Stanley (MS). The move raised concerns about just how much money the struggling bank needs to survive. Citigroup reports earnings Jan. 22. Analysts expect a loss of $1.14 a share, which would be its fifth straight quarter in the red. Shares of Citigroup fell 5% in the pre-market. Morgan Stanley lost about 4%.

Deutsche Bank (DB) tumbled 10% in the pre-market after warning of a huge Q4 loss. Citing an "exceptionally difficult market environment," the bank expects to lose $6.4 billion in the fourth quarter. The German financial services giant also restructured a deal to buy Deutsche Postbank.

Late Tuesday, Morgan Stanley warned that HSBC Holdings (HBC) might need to raise $30 billion in capital and cut its dividend by half. Morgan also slashed earnings estimates on Europe's biggest bank. HSBC shares slumped 7% in the pre-open.
In non-bank news, Yahoo (YHOO) rose 2% after naming Autodesk (ADSK) Chairman Carol Bartz as its new chief executive.

On the economic front, retail sales fell 2.7% in December. That was the sixth straight monthly drop and was more than double the 1.2% decline expected by economists. Excluding autos, sales slid 3.1%, also much worse than forecast.
Import prices declined 4.2% in December, while export prices slipped 2.3%.
The Fed's beige book on regional economic conditions will be out at 2 p.m. EST.

Elsewhere, crude oil slipped 36 cents to $37.42 a barrel amid Saudi Arabia's talk of even more production cuts.5:15 p.m. Update: Bad news from banks and more weak U.S. retail sales data triggered a broad-based slide Wednesday that ripped through Europe and the U.S.The skid extended the market's losing streak to six straight days on the Dow, four on the NYSE. Norfolk Southern plans to release its Q4 results after the close on Jan. 27.12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pare Losses A Bit Near Session's HalftimeBY VINCENT MAOStocks tried to rebound after sinking to intraday lows near the halfway point of Wednesday's session.The NYSE composite slumped 3.9%, S&P 500 3.4%, Nasdaq 3.2% and the Dow 3.1%.Turnover was again mixed, with NYSE's higher and Nasdaq's slightly lower. Decliners creamed advancers 14-to-1 on the NYSE and 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Leaders crumbled along with the general market.AECOM Technology (ACM) tumbled 11% on triple-paced volume, slicing its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The drop sent the government contractor below a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.AeroVironment (AVAV) dropped 8% and sliced its 50-day line on brisk trade. The maker of unmanned aircraft systems has staged two failed breakouts.Tower Group (TWGP) fell 5% in its fifth-straight down day. The insurance firm has given back all gains from its Dec. 30 breakout  and then some.All 197 industry groups tracked by IBD traded lower.11:15 a.m. Update: Banks Drag U.S. & European Markets Into Lockstep Slide BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes drilled with a passion in late morning trading. Oil and most commodities slumped as the dollar moved generally higher vs. overseas currencies.Financial issues led the NYSE composite's 4.3% slide. The S&P 500 bored out a 3.7% loss. The Nasdaq composite and the Dow skittered 3.5% and 3.4% lower.Volume was mixed, up 8% on the NYSE and 3% lower on the Nasdaq.All of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD gave up ground, with big banks, coal and solar issues and metals miners surrendering the largest gains.The Nymex February crude contract slipped $1.10 to below $37 a barrel. Weekly inventories showed a mild rise, but not enough to relieve the current domestic oil glut caused by soft demand and a futures market in contango. In London, the Brent crude benchmark added 76 cents to more than $45 a barrel.Other commodities were generally mixed as the dollar piled into a third day of gains vs. the euro, but backtracked against the yen.Private college operators grabbed some early gains, but backed off their highs in late morning trading.Apollo Group (APOL) held a 50-cent gain, a bit less than 1%, in heavy trading. ITT Educational Services (ESI) was also up just under 1% in equally strong trading action.On the medical side, patient support system maker Hill-Rom Holdings (HRC) managed a 3% gain in strong trading.On the downside, online jewelry retailer Blue Nile (NILE) shed 9% on nearly four times its average volume.Strayer Education (STRA) backed off 3% in busy action, working on a third straight day of declines.Overseas, markets in Asia booked varied gains. The Shanghai composite bolted ahead 3.5%, its best gain in six weeks, on speculation the central bank was preparing for its sixth interest rate cut since September. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index grabbed a more modest 0.3% gain. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo also added 0.3%.The picture was far less rosy in Europe and the U.K. Morgan Stanley's warning on HSBC Holdings' (HBC) finances and U.S. retail sales data drove stocks sharply lower. The FTSE 100 had tanked 5.4% heading into late afternoon trading. The CAC-40 in Paris axed off a 4.9% loss and Frankfurt's DAX dropped 4.3%.10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Down Sharply On Lower TradeBY VINCENT MAOStocks tumbled out of the gate and piled on more losses Wednesday, sending the major indexes further south of their 50-day moving averages.The NYSE composite dumped 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.6%, the Nasdaq 2.5% and the Dow 2.3%. Decliners swamped advancers by about 12-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges.Financials were among the biggest losers, with Citigroup (C) leading the pack. It gapped down and dropped 14%. The bank will report earnings on Friday instead of Jan. 22. It did not give a reason.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which moved its report date up to Thursday, fell 5%.Bunge (BG) gapped down and plunged 16% after late Tuesday's move to guide full-year 2008 and 2009 earnings below views. This morning UBS downgraded shares to neutral from buy.Siemens (SI) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped 12% after warning of tough times ahead. This morning Merrill Lynch cut the German conglomerate to neutral from buy.9:15 a.m. Update: Financials, Retail Sales Slam Stock FuturesBY VINCENT MAOStocks futures signaled a vastly lower start Wednesday on concerns over the health of the financial sector and dismal retail sales.Nasdaq futures declined 17 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 16 points and Dow futures shed 104 points.Late Tuesday, Citigroup (C) confirmed that it will merge its Smith Barney brokerage unit into a joint venture with Morgan Stanley (MS). The move raised concerns about just how much money the struggling bank needs to survive. Citigroup reports earnings Jan. 22. Analysts expect a loss of $1.14 a share, which would be its fifth straight quarter in the red. Shares of Citigroup fell 5% in the pre-market. Morgan Stanley lost about 4%.Deutsche Bank (DB) tumbled 10% in the pre-market after warning of a huge Q4 loss. Citing an "exceptionally difficult market environment," the bank expects to lose $6.4 billion in the fourth quarter. The German financial services giant also restructured a deal to buy Deutsche Postbank.Late Tuesday, Morgan Stanley warned that HSBC Holdings (HBC) might need to raise $30 billion in capital and cut its dividend by half. Morgan also slashed earnings estimates on Europe's biggest bank. HSBC shares slumped 7% in the pre-open.In non-bank news, Yahoo (YHOO) rose 2% after naming Autodesk (ADSK) Chairman Carol Bartz as its new chief executive.On the economic front, retail sales fell 2.7% in December. That was the sixth straight monthly drop and was more than double the 1.2% decline expected by economists. Excluding autos, sales slid 3.1%, also much worse than forecast.Import prices declined 4.2% in December, while export prices slipped 2.3%.The Fed's beige book on regional economic conditions will be out at 2 p.m. EST.Elsewhere, crude oil slipped 36 cents to $37.42 a barrel amid Saudi Arabia's talk of even more production cuts.
5:15 p.m. Update: The week wound down to an unremarkable finish, with indexes giving up early gains to end mixed in heavy options-expiration trading.

The Nasdaq ended 0.8% higher and the S&P 500 edged up 0.3%. The NYSE composite was a fraction into the red. The Dow, slipping 0.3% on a quadruple-witching boost from options expirations, logged its third distribution day since the Dec. 2 follow-through.
Still, three of the four major indexes gained ground for the week. The NYSE composite added 1.3% and the Nasdaq 1.5%. The S&P 500 edged 0.9% higher, while the Dow slipped 0.6%.
For the NYSE, Nasdaq and S&P 500 it was the first two-week advance since September. The Dow hasn't managed a two-week gain since May.
In addition, all the major indexes eased in late trading, losing the week's battle to hold above their 50-day moving averages.

No significant economic news is scheduled for release Monday. But Tuesday's releases will include new and existing home sales, GDP data and the University of Michigan's revised Consumer Sentiment index numbers for December.
Drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) and software maker Red Hat (RHT) are scheduled to report earnings Monday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Mixed After Volatile Session
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
A volatile session ended with mixed results Friday.
The Dow fell 0.4%, weighed down mostly by oil components Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), as crude continued sliding.
The NYSE composite edged down a fraction, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Nasdaq 0.8%, according to early figures.
Volume rose amid options expiration-related trading. The market heads into one of its quietest weeks, shortened by the Christmas holiday.
Automakers and auto-supplier stocks rose after the White House agreed to provide emergency loans to the Big Three.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hold Gains, But Settle To Lower End of Ranges
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
A back-and-forth session held to positive territory, as decliners led advancing issues by healthy margins. But the day's heavy-volume trading bypassed most leading stocks.
The Nasdaq composite held top honors, up 1.3%. The S&P 500 kept 0.9% in the black, while the Dow and NYSE composite clung to 0.4% gains.

Research in Motion (RIMM) and Oracle (ORCL) continued to be heavy upside players on the Nasdaq. Energy and international plays lagged on the NYSE. Small caps continued riding ahead of the mainstream, driving the S&P 600 up better than 2%.
Volume continued to settle toward more normal ranges, but remained 78% higher on the NYSE and up 23% on the Nasdaq.

Oil prices split in late trading. The expiring January contract shed $2.35 to settle at $33.87. The February contract climbed rose 69 cents to $42.36, leaving the front month contract down 8% for the week.

Aaron Rents (RNT) climbed 5%, breaking above a 26.68 buy point on a 13-week, cup-with-handle base. The rent-to-own chain announced Tuesday it would acquire Missouri-based Rosey Rentals, a franchisee operating 35 Aaron's stores in six states in the Southeast with annual revenue of about $45 million.

Quality Systems (QSII) cut losses for a 4% run, but volume was just a shade above average. The maker of health care practice and records management software has jumped 16% so far this week as it works to build the right side of a base.

On the downside, Italian oil & gas heavyweight Eni Spa  (E) slipped 7% as oil prices sculpted out multiyear lows. Eni has been in a general uptrend since early October and is holding its own above support at its 10-week moving average.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Rebound In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
The major stock indexes bounced back in afternoon trading Friday but remained off session highs.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.1%, while the Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.6% each.
Volume continued to track sharply higher, but the pace had slowed.
PetMed Express (PETS) rallied 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. The pet pharmacy operator may be forming a base.
Research In Motion (RIMM) rallied 9% in heavy trading. Despite hovering near two-year lows, the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B from a worst-possible E in October.

On the downside, AeroVironment (AVAV) extended losses to 10% and is off more than 8% from its buy point. The unmanned aircraft systems maker cleared a 36.32 buy point from a base-on-base pattern Thursday.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) dropped 4% and sliced is 10-week and 40-week moving averages. The stock also triggered the 8% sell rule. It passed a 42.85 buy point from a double-bottom base Wednesday. William Blair & Co. warned that deflation may hurt the farming equipment retailer.
Crude oil dropped $1.90 to $34.32 a barrel. Energy stocks were mixed.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Tinker With Mixed Territory; Small Caps Outperform
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes threw in the towel after an early surge spurred by news of a federal bailout for U.S. automakers.
The NYSE composite slipped briefly into the red, then managed a fractional gain. The Dow flattened. The S&P 500 held a 0.5% advance and the Nasdaq composite showed a 0.9% rise.

Financial issues dragged on the Nasdaq, with the exchange's financial index down 1.3%. Computer, telecom and insurance sectors still held better-than-1% gains. On the NYSE, the International 100 index lagged with a 1% decline, and technology stocks tracked close behind. Small caps ran well ahead of the curve, with the S&P 600 up 2%.
Volume eased from its early highs, but remained at extraordinary levels  particularly on the NYSE  because of options expiration trading.
Crude oil prices ground lower, down more than $1 after dipping to midsession lows below $34 a barrel. Gold held the bulk of its early losses, remaining down more than $22 to below $838 an ounce.
Flowers Foods (FLO) cooked up a 4% gain as it tried to notch its first weekly gain in December. Shares are still well below their 50- and 200-day moving averages in a consolidation begun in August.

Onyx Pharmaceuticals  (ONXX) swung 5% higher in above-average volume. The biotech drug maker is in its fourth straight week of gains, has topped resistance at its 10-week line and appears ready to take a run at the 40-week level.

On the downside, advanced ceramic components maker Ceradyne (CRDN) gapped down and surrendered 20% after a downgrade from buy to hold from Stanford Research. The big-volume tumble punched the stock back below support at its 50-day line. It has been trying to build a floor to a consolidation begun in August.
12:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Retreat Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back sharply near the halftime of Friday's session. Most major indexes slipped back under their respective 50-day moving averages after regaining them earlier.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.4%, down from an intraday high of 2.6%. The S&P 500 rose 1%, Dow 0.6% and NYSE composite 0.4%.
Volume was again tracking vastly higher across the board due to quadruple expiration and the quarterly rebalancing of S&P indexes.
Tower Group (TWGP) tacked on 9% in heavy trading, its fourth straight advance. The insurance firm is nearing a potential 27.63 buy point from a cup base.
Gentiva Health Services (GTIV) gapped up and gained 3% in brisk trade. After a failed breakout earlier this month, the home health care firm is forming a new handle with a buy point at 28.36.

On the downside, Supertex (SUPX) gapped down and dropped 7% after cutting its sales outlook. The chipmaker now expects revenue in the range of $17 million to $18 million, down from a prior forecast of $21.3 million to $22.3 million. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Atmel (ATML), Atheros Communications (ATHR), MEMC Electronic Materials (WFR), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Xilinx (XLNX) have all slashed their earnings and/or sales guidances.
AeroVironment (AVAV) lost 4% in active trading, slipping below a 36.32 buy point cleared Thursday.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Drive To Solid Gains With Options Expiration Support
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes swept higher in broad-based gains, with advancing issues leading by better than 4-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 3-to-1 margin on the Nasdaq.
The Nasdaq composite scored a 2.5% rise, with Oracle (ORCL), Research In Motion (RIMM) and Comcast (CMCSA) driving the Nasdaq 100.
The S&P 500 flashed a 2% advance, the Dow climbed 1.8% and the NYSE composite rode 1.5% higher.
On the NYSE, energy, financials and health care pulled ahead of other sectors.
NYSE volume erupted in quadruple witching action, up nearly 250%. Nasdaq volume soared 67% above Thursday's below-average volume.

Commodities traded generally mixed as crude futures hovered, holding near a 4-1/2 year low just below $36 a barrel. The dollar strengthened vs. the euro. Gold slumped more than $25 to below $836 an ounce.

S&P 400 component Highwood Properties (HIW) phoned in an 8% jump on more than double its average trading volume. The Southeast/Midwest commercial property REIT sports a best possible 99 EPS Rating from IBD. It appears set to end its second week above its 10-week moving average as it climbs up from a three-month consolidation.

California Water Services (CWT) launched into a 4% gain in heavy trade. The move began what would be a fourth straight day of gains for the multistate public and commercial water utility. Shares are up 14% so far this week, clearing new highs for the first time since 2006 and 8% above a 42.60 buy point on a rebound from the stock's 10-week moving average.

On the downside, heavy construction firm Fluor (FLR) slipped 7% in busy trading. The company, which has strong ties to refining and energy industry construction, has suffered from the fall in oil prices. Shares are down 6% so far for the week, hurting the stock's effort to build a right side to a six-month consolidation.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Pare Gains After Higher Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks charged out of the gate Friday after automakers received their long-awaited bailout, but the major indexes have already shaved a chunk of gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.3%, thanks to gains in a number of high-profile tech issues and chip stocks. The Dow rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.5%. The NYSE composite was mostly unchanged.
Volume was tracking vastly higher due to quadruple expiration of stock options, stock index options, stock index futures and single stock futures.
Provident Bankshares (PBKS) gapped up and skyrocketed 58% on news that it will be acquired by M & T Bank for $401 million in stock.

Research In Motion (RIMM) rose 5% in fast trade following a round of mixed analysts' actions. Cowen & Co. cut the BlackBerry maker to underperform from neutral, while Raymond James and UBS both cut the stock's price target. TD Bank Financial raised shares to Action List Buy from Buy.
On the downside, AECOM Technology (ACM) fell 3% as it slipped for a second session. That left the government contractor 5% past a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
January crude pared losses, but was still down 53 cents to $35.69 a barrel.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Higher Start As Automakers Get Bailed Out
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a higher open Friday after the While House announced help for U.S. automakers.
Nasdaq futures rose 12 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 9 points and Dow futures gained 112 points.
General Motors (GM) and Chrysler will split $13.4 billion in loans to help them stave off bankruptcy. They'll split another $4 billion in February and must show "financial viability" by March.
GM shares rose 7% in the pre-market. Ford (F), which has said it doesn't need bailout money, rose 5%.

Standard & Poor's Ratings Services cut ratings on a slew of major U.S. and European banks, citing rising risks amid the worsening recession. The list of downgraded firms includes Bank of America (BAC), Barclays (BCS), Citigroup (C), Credit Suisse Group (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Royal Bank of Scotland Group (RBS), UBS (UBS) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
S&P also lowered HSBC's (HBC) outlook to negative. The U.K. bank fell 3% in the pre-market.

On the upside, Oracle (ORCL) gained nearly 4% in the pre-open on its bright fiscal Q3 outlook. Amid a weak tech spending environment, the database software maker sees current quarter sales growing 8% to 11% vs. views of 8%. Earnings are pegged at 34 cents to 36 cents a share vs. views of 34 cents.

Intrepid Potash (IPI) cut its Q4 sales outlook, while fellow fertilizer maker Potash Corp. Of Saskatchewan (POT) cut its full-year profit guidance. Intrepid fell 14% in the pre-market, while Potash Corp. shed 3%.
Elsewhere, Panasonic offered to buy rival Sanyo for $9 billion.

Crude oil rebounded slightly after touching its lowest level in nearly five years. The expiring January contract fell $1.42 to $34.08 a barrel. Earlier, it hit $33.44, the lowest since February 2004.5:15 p.m. Update: The week wound down to an unremarkable finish, with indexes giving up early gains to end mixed in heavy options-expiration trading.The Nasdaq ended 0.8% higher and the S&P 500 edged up 0.3%. The list of downgraded firms includes Bank of America (BAC), Barclays (BCS), Citigroup (C), Credit Suisse Group (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Royal Bank of Scotland Group (RBS), UBS (UBS) and Wells Fargo (WFC).S&P also lowered HSBC's (HBC) outlook to negative. The U.K. bank fell 3% in the pre-market.On the upside, Oracle (ORCL) gained nearly 4% in the pre-open on its bright fiscal Q3 outlook. Amid a weak tech spending environment, the database software maker sees current quarter sales growing 8% to 11% vs. views of 8%. Earnings are pegged at 34 cents to 36 cents a share vs. views of 34 cents.Intrepid Potash (IPI) cut its Q4 sales outlook, while fellow fertilizer maker Potash Corp. Of Saskatchewan (POT) cut its full-year profit guidance. Intrepid fell 14% in the pre-market, while Potash Corp. shed 3%.Elsewhere, Panasonic offered to buy rival Sanyo for $9 billion.Crude oil rebounded slightly after touching its lowest level in nearly five years. The expiring January contract fell $1.42 to $34.08 a barrel. Earlier, it hit $33.44, the lowest since February 2004.
5:15 p.m. Update:  A curveball session saw brief, midday light above the break-even line before indexes dipped into losses across the board.
The Dow shoveled out a 1.1% loss and the S&P 500 fell 1%. The composites, NYSE and Nasdaq, slipped 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively.

But all indexes held above their 50-day moving averages, making it the first two-day foray above that line of resistance since September for the Nasdaq, the Dow and the S&P 500. For the NYSE, it was the first two-day stint above 50-day support since June.
Midcaps and small caps saw notable buying interest, pushing the S&P 400 to a 1% gain and the S&P 600 ahead 1.1%.

Late trading volume ran up against hard comparisons due to Tuesday's surge in afternoon action. So while volume had tracked steadily higher across the early parts of the session, comparative volumes sank in late trading to end lower overall. Trade was down 13% on the NYSE and 4% lower on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.
Advancing issues led decliners by about 3-to-2 on the NYSE. On the Nasdaq, decliners led by a narrow margin.
4:15 p.m. Update: Market Closes Lower As Volume Fades
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
Stocks pared losses but still closed lower Wednesday, giving back part of Tuesday's huge gains.
The Dow lost 1.1%, the S&P 500 1% and the NYSE composite 0.6%, according to preliminary figures. The Nasdaq, weighed down by Apple's (AAPL) 7% loss, fell 0.7%.
Volume dropped.
Health care and financial groups fared worst. Transportation stocks rose as crude prices slid despite a record OPEC output cut.
Most leading stocks made modest moves.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Lower As Financials Soften
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Big banks hauled indexes back from their highs and into negative territory in late trading as the dollar continued to soften and oil plunged into its close.
The Dow slipped 0.6% while the NYSE composite and the S&P 500 each dropped 0.3%. The Nasdaq was down 0.4%.
Volume was tracking 17% higher on the NYSE and 20% higher on the Nasdaq. More than 70% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD were up, however.
Financials tumbled while biotechs continued to post gains.

Oil toppled 8% to settle pennies above $40 a barrel, despite the largest production cut in OPEC's history and a sharply declining dollar. Natural gas also lost ground. Other commodities generally posted gains.
AECOM Technology (ACM) scored a 5% advance in heavy trading. The move pushed the construction industry services provider to 14% above the 27.30 buy point on a 14-week cup-with-handle base.

AeroVironment (AVAV) rocked 4% higher in firm volume. That put shares just below a 36.32 buy point in a seven-week, cup-with-handle base. The military drone and alternative energy firm is 7% below the record high set Nov. 4.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Reach Positive Ground
BY VINCENT MAO
After some hesitation near the flat line, stocks pushed into positive ground in afternoon trading Wednesday.

The NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. The Dow rose 0.4%. And the Nasdaq climbed 0.5%, regaining its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq had been down nearly 2% at session lows.
Volume was still tracking sharply higher across the board, and the pace had picked up.

Nike (NKE) ran up 3%, but met resistance at its 50-day moving average. The athletic apparel and shoe maker reports fiscal Q2 results after the close. Analysts expect 78 cents a share on sales of $4.69 million.
Likewise, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) gained 3%, and it too found resistance at its 50-day line. The stock is forming a possible handle with a buy point at 38.54.
On the downside, Adobe Systems (ADBE) reversed morning gains and lost 2%. The software maker was up 7% following last night's earnings report.
1:15 p.m. Update: Rebound Efforts Wane In Midday Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
The major indexes were close to positive territory, but rebound efforts faded in midday trading Wednesday.
The Nasdaq fell 0.6%, the NYSE composite 0.4%. The Dow and S&P 500 slipped 0.5% each.
Turnover continued to track vastly higher across the board.
Axsys Technologies (AXYS)reversed early gains and fell 5% in fast trade. The maker of motion-control systems cleared a handle from a double-bottom base Dec. 3 but quickly faltered.

On the upside, AeroVironment (AVAV) reversed its earlier loss and added 2%. The stock is adding a handle to its base-on-base pattern. The unmanned aircraft systems maker ranks No. 6 in this week's IBD 100.
Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (TEVA) gapped up and gained 3% in fast trade. Citigroup started coverage of the Israeli drug maker at buy, while JPMorgan initiated an overweight rating.
Elsewhere, crude oil extended losses despite a big production cut by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. January crude fell $2.34 to $41.21 a barrel.
Gold gained $28.10 to $870.80 an ounce.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Pare Losses Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO AND ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Stocks remained lower near the halfway point of Wednesday's session, but were trying to rebound.
The Dow, Nasdaq and S&P 500 fell 1% each. The NYSE composite lost 0.9%.
A couple of IBD 100 firms fell on downgrades.
Volume was still tracking sharply higher across the board. Declining stocks topped advancers by 3-to-2 on the Nasdaq and by 4-to-3 on the NYSE.

Sterling Construction (STRL) dropped 6% in active trading, but the stock appears to be finding support at its 200-day moving average. BB&T Capital Markets cut shares of the infrastructure builder to hold from buy. Sterling may be forming a handle.
Insituform Technologies  (INSU) lost 8% after Janney Montgomery Scott downgraded the pipe maker to neutral from buy. The broker cited valuation, after the stock doubled from its July low.

On the upside, Hansen Natural (HANS) popped 6% in fast trade. That pushed the beverage maker further north of its 200-day moving average. The stock regained the line Tuesday after trading under it for nearly a year.
Gold issues rallied in strong volume as the precious metal jumped $27.20 to $869.90 an ounce.
Barrick Gold (ABX) rallied 6% and regained its 200-day line.
Agnico Eagle Mines (AEM) and Goldcorp (GG) rose 3% each.

Meanwhile, crude oil headed lower, down more than $1.50 to near $42 a barrel, not the expected reaction to a vote by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production by 2.2 million barrels a day. The cut was larger than expected and the biggest reduction in the group's history.
11:15 a.m. Update: Losses Deepen In Solid Trading
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT

Tech-sector stocks took some of the hardest hits as indexes drifted deeper into losses. Energy and commodity issues generally held their ground ahead of word about a possible production cut from OPEC.

The Nasdaq composite slipped 1.1%, and the Dow drifted to a 1% loss. The NYSE composite and the S&P 500 each registered 0.9% declines. The Nasdaq's biotech and transportation sectors posted gains, while computers makers, led by Apple's (AAPL) 7% loss, pulled hardest to the downside. On the NYSE, energy-sector issues posted gains while financials had the heaviest losses.
Trading tracked firmly above Tuesday's slightly below average trading levels, up 9% on the NYSE and 18% on the Nasdaq.

Oil hovered little changed, focusing on a possible announcement from OPEC regarding production later in the day, rather than on weekly crude inventories, which rose by a half-million barrels vs. expectations for a near 1-million-barrel decline. Commodities were generally mixed, though gold shot up $33 to above $875 an ounce.
Syngenta (SYT) sprang for a 5% gain, climbing further out of a consolidation started in June. The maker of crop protection products is up 13% so far this week.

Diversified food manufacturer Ralcorp Holdings (RAH) gobbled up a 2% advance in heavy trading. The move begins the stock's eighth gain in the past nine sessions, as it climbs back toward its 200-day moving average.

On the downside, MWI Veterinary Supply (MWIV) toppled 15% in very fast trading. No particular news seemed to drive the loss, but it did show shares losing a bid to beat resistance at their 50-day moving average.

Overseas, most Asian markets closed moderately higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index jumped the most, notching a 2.2% gain, led by property stocks reacting to Tuesday's fed funds lending rate cut in the U.S.

In Europe and the U.K., modest losses were the theme. Energy and commodities stocks gained on expectations of rising oil prices and a possible production cut from OPEC later today. But banks and financials dragged London's FTSE 100 down 0.7%, Frankfurt's DAX down 1.1% and the CAC-40 in Paris down 0.8%.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fight Back From Lower Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stumbled out of the gate Wednesday, but have already shaved a chunk of losses.
The NYSE composite lost 0.9%, while the Dow and S&P 500 each fell 0.8%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq lost 0.8%, falling under its 50-day moving average.
Volume was tracking higher across the board.

Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) gapped down and slumped 6% after lowering guidance and announcing a round of layoffs. Citing economic challenges, the household products maker now expects Q4 profit in a range of 6 cents to 10 cents a share, down from a prior outlook of 29 cents to 34 cents. Revenue is slated to fall in the low teens. Newell will also slash up to 1,000 non-manufacturing jobs.
Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) declined 6% after cutting its dividend for the second time this year. The bank slashed its Q4 dividend to a penny a share, down from 15 cents in the third quarter.

On the upside, Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up and gained 5% after reporting earnings above views late Tuesday. The software maker also backed its Q1 outlook for earnings between 43 cents and 47 cents a share on sales of $800 million to $850 million.
Satyam Computer Services (SAY) gapped up and surged 31% after deciding against its proposed buyout of Maytas Properties and Maytas Infra.
Elsewhere, crude oil turned lower ahead of the energy inventories report. January crude slipped 23 cents to $43.37 a barrel.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Soft Start
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a lower open Wednesday, as equities look to pull back from Tuesday's Fed-inspired pop.
Nasdaq futures dropped 15 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures shed 7 points and Dow futures lost 84 points.

Morgan Stanley (MS) tumbled 9% in the pre-market after reporting a bigger-than-expected Q4 loss. The bank lost nearly $2.2 billion, or $2.24 a share, as the credit crisis continued to eat into its bottom line. Though that was better than the prior year's $3.61 per-share shortfall, it was much worse than views for a loss of 34 cents.
Group mate Goldman Sachs (GS), which reported Tuesday, fell 3%.
Deutsche Bank (DB) stumbled 11% in the pre-open following a downgrade. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods cut the bank's shares to market perform from outperform, citing increasing industry risks.
Other financials were also under pressure. Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) each lost 3%.

Meanwhile, Oppenheimer & Co. cut Apple (AAPL) to perform from outperform on concerns over Chief Executive Steve Jobs' health. Late Tuesday Apple said Jobs would not deliver the keynote speech at next month's Macworld trade show. Shares fell 5% in the pre-market.

After Tuesday's close, chipmaker Xilinx  (XLNX) cut its Q3 revenue forecast due to weaker-than-anticipated December sales. The company sees sales falling 6% to 10% below its second-quarter results. That implies revenue in a range of $435.2 million to $454.5 million vs. views of $458.5 million. Shares fell 3%.

Fellow chipmaker Silicon Laboratories (SLAB) shed 3% in the pre-market after slashing its Q4 guidance. The company now expects earnings in a range of 34 cents to 36 cents a share, down from a prior outlook of 41 cents to 46 cents. Sales are seen in a range of $100 million to $102 million vs. a prior range of $107.8 million to $113.5 million. Consensus estimates call for earnings of 41 cents a share on sales of $107.6 million.
A number of chip firms have lowered their outlooks recently. Still, the Philadelphia semiconductor index has gained more than 23% since its November low.

Elsewhere, crude oil rose 43 cents to $44.03 a barrel ahead of the weekly energy inventories report at 10:35 a.m. EST. Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries also meet today. A production cut of up to 2 million barrels is expected.5:15 p.m. Update:  A curveball session saw brief, midday light above the break-even line before indexes dipped into losses across the board.The Dow shoveled out a 1.1% loss and the S&P 500 fell 1%.
